  </tr>
</table>

<div  class='figright id031'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_55'>55</span>
<img src='images/i_073.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 38.</span>—Larva (<i>a</i>) of a chalcid, about to pupate, with the head, including the eyes and three ocelli, in the prothoracic segment: <i>b</i>, <i>c</i>, pupa.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>The composition of the head in the Hymenoptera.</b>—Ratzeburg stated
in 1832 that the head in the adult Hymenoptera (Cynips, Hemiteles,
and Formica) does not correspond to that of the larva, but is derived
from the head and the first thoracic segment of the larva. Westwood
and also Goureau made less complete but similar observations,
though Westwood afterwards changed his opinion, and the same
view was maintained by Reinhard. Our own observations (as seen
in Fig. 38) led us to suppose that this was a mistaken view; that
the larval head, being too small to contain that of the semipupa, was
simply pushed forward, as in caterpillars. Bugnion, however, reaffirms
it in such a detailed way that we reproduce his account. He
maintains that the
views of Ratzeburg
are exact and easy to
verify in the chalcid
genus Encyrtus, except,
however, that
which concerns the
ventral part and the
posterior border of
the prothoracic segment.</p>

<p class='c007'>As the time of
transformation approaches,
the head of
the larva, he says, is
depressed and soon
concealed under the
edge of the prothoracic
segment; the latter elongates, becomes thicker and more convex,
and within can be seen the two oculo-cephalic imaginal buds.
The head of the perfect insect is derived not only from the head of
the larva, but also from the portion of the prothoracic segment which
is occupied by the buds, <i>i.e.</i> almost its entire dorsolateral face. But
the hinder and ventral part of this segment (which contains the
imaginal buds of the first pair of legs) takes no part in the formation
of the head; these parts, according to Bugnion, towards the end
of the larval period detaching themselves so as to become fused with
the thorax and constitute the pronotum and the prosternum.</p>

<div  class='figleft id011'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_56'>56</span>
<img src='images/i_074a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 39.</span>—Anterior half of larva of Encyrtus, ventral face, showing the upper (wing) and lower (leg) thoracic imaginal buds: <i>b</i>, mouth; <i>ch</i>, chitinous arch; <i>gl</i>, silk gland; <i>g</i>, brain; <i>n</i>, nervous cord; <i>a</i><sup>1</sup>, bud of fore, <i>a</i><sup>2</sup>, bud of hind, wing; <i>p</i><sup>1</sup>–<i>p</i><sup>3</sup>, buds of legs; <i>st</i><sup>1</sup>–<i>st</i><sup>3</sup>, stigmata.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id012'>
<img src='images/i_074b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 40.</span>—Anterior part of Encyrtus larva, 1.2 mm. in length; dorsal face; the cellular masses beginning to form the buds of the wings, eyes, and antennæ: <i>o</i>, eye bud; <i>e</i>, stomach.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class='section'>

</div>
<div  class='figleft id012'>
<img src='images/i_074c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 41.</span>—Older Encyrtus larva, lateral view, showing the buds of the antennæ (<i>f</i>), legs, and wings; <i>oe</i>, œsophagus; <i>q</i><sup>1</sup>, <i>q</i><sup>2</sup>, <i>q</i><sup>3</sup>, buds of the genital armature; <i>x</i>, rudiment of the sexual gland (ovary or testis); <i>u</i>, urinary tube; <i>i</i>, intestine (rectum); <i>a</i>, anus.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id024'>
<img src='images/i_074d.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 42.</span>—A still older larva, ready to transform. The imaginal buds of the antennæ, eyes, wings, and legs have become elongated; lettering as in Fig. 41.—This and Figs. 39–41 after Bugnion.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div><span class='pageno' id='Page_57'>57</span></div>
<div class='section'>

</div>
<p class='c013'>This mode of formation of the head may be observed still more easily in
Rhodites, Hemiteles, and Microgaster, from the fact that their oculo-cephalic
buds are much more precocious, and that the eyes are charged with pigment at
a period when the insect still preserves its larval form.</p>

<p class='c013'>“... I believe that this mode of formation of the head occurs in all Hymenoptera
with apodous larvæ, in this sense; that a more or less considerable part
of the first thoracic segment is always soldered to the head of the larva to constitute
the head of the perfect insect. The arrangement of the nervous system
is naturally in accord with this peculiarity of development, and the cephalic
ganglia of the larva to which the ocular blastems later adapt themselves, are
found not in the head, but in the succeeding segment (Figs. 39, 40, 41).</p>

<p class='c013'>“Relying on these facts, I maintain that the encroachment of the head on
the prothorax is a consequence of the preponderance in size of the brain, and
indicates the superiority of the Hymenoptera over other insects....”</p>

<p class='c013'>That the pronotum is derived from the larval prothoracic segment is proved
by the fact that the first pair of stigmata becomes what authors call the “prothoracic”
stigmata of the perfect insect. But Bugnion thinks that the projection
which carries it, and which he calls the shoulder (Figs. 41 and 42), belongs
to the mesonotum.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>b.</i> Appendages of the head</h4>

<p class='c016'><b>The antennæ.</b>—These are organs of tactile sense, but also bear
olfactory, and in some cases auditory organs; they are usually inserted
between or in front of the eyes, and moved by two small
muscles at the base, within the head. In the more generalized
insects the antennæ are simple, many-jointed appendages, the joints
being equal in size and shape. The antennæ articulate with the
head by a ball and socket joint, the part on which it moves being
called the <i>torulus</i> (Fig. 32, <i>r</i>). In the more specialized forms it is
divided into the <i>scape</i>, the <i>pedicel</i>, and a <i>flagellum</i> (or <i>clavola</i>); but
usually, as in ants, wasps, and bees, there are two parts, the basal
three-jointed one being the scape, and the distal one, the usually long
filiform flagellum. The antennæ, especially the flagellum, vary
greatly in form in insects of different families and orders, this variation
being the result of adaptation to their peculiar surroundings and
habits. The number of antennal joints may be one (Articerus, a
clavigerid beetle), or two in Paussus and in <i>Adranes cœcus</i> (Fig. 43<sup>12</sup>),
where they are short and club-shaped; in flies (Muscidæ, etc.), they
are very short and with few joints, and when at rest lying in a cavity
adapted for their reception. In the lamellicorn beetles the flagellum
is divided into several leaves, and this condition may be approached
in the serrate or flabellicorn antennæ of other beetles. In Lepidoptera,
and in certain saw-flies and beetles, they are either pectinate
or bipectinate, being in one case at least, that of the Australian
Hepialid (<i>Abantiades argenteus</i>), tripectinate (Fig. 44), and in the
dipterous (Tachinid) genus Talarocera the third joint is bipectinate
(Fig. 45). In Xenos and in Parnus they may be deeply forked,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_58'>58</span>while in Otiocerus, two long processes arise from the base, giving it
a trifid shape. In dragon-flies and cicadæ, they are minute and
hair-like, though jointed, while in the larvæ of many metabolous
insects they are reduced to minute three-jointed tubercles. In
aquatic beetles, bugs, etc., the antennæ are short, and often, when
at rest, bent close to the body, as long antennæ would impede
their progress.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id004'>
<img src='images/i_076a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 43.</span>—Different forms of antennæ of beetles: 1, serrate; 2, pectinate; 3, capitate (and also geniculate); 4–7, clavate; 8, 9, lamellate; 10, serrate (Dorcatoma); 11, irregular (Gyrinus); 12, two-jointed antenna of <i>Adranes cæcus</i>.—After LeConte. <i>a</i>, first joint of flagellum of antenna of <i>Troctes silvarum</i>; <i>b</i>, of <i>T. divinatorius</i>.—After Kolbe.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id032'>
<img src='images/i_076b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 44.</span>—Tripectinate antenna of an Australian moth.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>While usually more or less sensorial in function,
Graber states that the longicorn beetles in walking
along a slender twig use their antennæ as a rope-dancer
does his balancing pole.</p>

<div  class='figright id027'>
<img src='images/i_076c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 45.</span>—Antenna of <i>Talarocera nigripennis</i>, ♂.—After Williston.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>Recent examination of the sense-organs in the
antennæ of an ant,
wasp, or bee enables
us, he says, to realize
what wonderful organs
the antennæ are.
In such insects we
have a rod-like tube
which can be folded
up or extended out
into space, containing
the antennal nerve,
which arises directly from the brain and sends a branch to each of
the thousands of olfactory pits or pegs which stud its surface. The
antenna is thus a wonderfully complex organ, and the insect must
<span class='pageno' id='Page_59'>59</span>be far more sensitive to movements of the air, to odors, wave-sounds,
and light-waves, than any of the vertebrate animals.</p>

<p class='c007'>That ants appear to communicate with each other, apparently
talking with their antennæ, shows the highly sensitive nature of
these appendages. “The honey-bee when constructing its cells ascertains
their proper direction and size by means of the extremities
of these organs.” (Newport.)</p>

<p class='c007'>How dependent insects are upon their antennæ is seen when we
cut them off. The insect is at once seriously affected, its central
nervous system receiving a great shock, while it gives no such sign
of distress and loss of mental power when we remove the palpi or
legs. On depriving a bee of its antennæ, it falls helpless and partially
paralyzed to the earth, is unable at first to walk, but on partly
recovering the use of its limbs, it still has lost the power of coördinating
its movements, nor can it sting; in a few minutes, however, it
becomes able to feebly walk a few steps, but it remains over an hour
nearly motionless. Other insects after similar treatment are not so
deeply affected, though bees, wasps, ants, moths, certain beetles, and
dragon-flies are at first more or less stunned and confused.</p>

<p class='c007'>The antennæ afford salient secondary sexual differences, as seen
in the broadly pectinated antennæ of male bombycine moths, certain
saw-flies (Lophyrus), and many other insects.</p>

<p class='c007'>The mouth-parts, buccal appendages, or trophi, comprise, besides
the labrum, the mandibles and maxillæ.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The mandibles.</b>—These are true jaws, adapted for cutting, tearing,
or crushing the food, or for defence, while in the bees they are used
as tools for modelling in wax, and in Cetonia, etc., as a brush for
collecting pollen. They are usually opposed to each other at the
tips, but in many carnivorous forms their tips cross each other like
shears. They are situated below the clypeus on each side, and are
hinged to the head by a true ginglymus articulation, consisting of
two condyles or tubercles to which muscles are attached, the principal
ones being the flexor and great extensor (Fig. 48). They are
solid, chitinous, of varied shapes, and in the form of the teeth those
of the same pair differ somewhat from each other (Fig. 46 <i>A</i>). In
the pollen-eating beetles (Cetoniæ) and in the dung-beetles (Aphodius,
etc.) the edge is soft and flexible. In the males of Lucanus, etc.
(Fig. 47), and of Corydalus (Fig. 29), they are of colossal size, and
are large and sabre-shaped in the larvæ of water-beetles, ant-lions,
Chrysopa, etc. where they are perforated at the tips, through which
the blood of their prey is sucked.</p>

<p class='c007'>While the mandibles are generally regarded as composed of a
<span class='pageno' id='Page_60'>60</span>single piece, in Campodea and Machilis there appears to be an
additional basal piece apparently corresponding to the stipes of the
first maxilla, and separated by a faint suture from the molar or
distal joint. In Campodea there is a minute movable appendage
figured both by Meinert and by Nassonow,
which appears to represent the lacinia of the
maxilla (Fig. 48). Wood-Mason has observed
in the mandibles of the embryo of a Javanese
cockroach, <i>Blatta (Panesthia) javanica</i>, indications
of “the same number of joints as in
that of chilognathous myriopods, or one less
than in that of Machilis.” Also he adds:
“In both ‘larvæ’ and adults of <i>Panesthia
javanica</i> a faint groove crosses the ‘back’ of
the mandible at the base. This groove appears to be the remains of
the joint between the third and apical segments of the formerly
4–segmented mandibles.”</p>

<div  class='figcenter id005'>
<img src='images/i_078a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 46.</span>—Various forms of mandibles. <i>A</i>, right and left of Termopsis. <i>A′</i>, showing at the shaded portion the “molar” of Smith. <i>B</i>, <i>Termes flavipes</i>, soldier; <i>md</i>, its mandible. <i>C</i>, Panorpa.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id033'>
<img src='images/i_078b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 47.</span>—<i>Chiasognathus grantii</i>, reduced. Male.—After Darwin.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id031'>
<img src='images/i_078c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 48.</span>—Mandible of Campodea: <i>l</i>, prostheca or lacinia; <i>g</i>, galea; <i>f</i>, <i>f</i>, flexor muscles; <i>e</i>, extensor; <i>r</i>, <i>r</i>, retractor; <i>rt</i>, muscle retaining the mandible in its place.—After Meinert. <i>A</i>, extremity of the same.—After Nassonow.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id034'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_61'>61</span>
<img src='images/i_079.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 49.</span>—Mandible of <i>Passalus cornutus</i> with the prostheca (<i>l</i>): <i>A</i>, that of a Nicaraguan species; <i>a</i>, inside, <i>b</i>, outside view, with the muscle.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>He also refers to the <i>prostheca</i> of Kirby and Spence (Fig. 49),
which he thinks appears to be a mandibular lacinia homologous with
it in Staphylinidæ and other beetles (J. B. Smith also considers it
as “homologous to the lacinia of the maxilla”), and on examining
it in <i>P. cornutus</i> and a Nicaragua species (Fig. 49), we adopt his view,
since we have found that it is freely movable and attached by a
tendon and muscle to the galea. In the rove beetles (Goërius, Staphylinus,
etc.) and in the subaquatic Heteroceridæ, instead of a molar
process, is a membranous setose appendage not unlike the coxal
appendages of Scolopendrella, movably articulated to the jaw, which
he thinks answers to the molar branch of the jaws in Blatta and
Machilis. “It has its homologue in the diminutive Trichopterygidæ
in the firmly chitinized quadrant-shaped second
mandibular joint, which is used in a peculiar
manner in crushing the food”; also in the movable
tooth of the Passalidæ, and
in the membranous inner
lobe of the mandibles of
the goliath-beetles, etc.</p>

<p class='c007'>J. B. Smith has clearly
shown that the mandibles
are compound in certain of
the lamellicorns. In <i>Copris
carolina</i> (Fig. 50), he says,
the small membranous
mandibles are divided into
a basal piece (basalis), the
homologue of the stipes in the maxilla; another of the basal pieces
he calls the molar, and this is the equivalent of the subgalea, while
a third sclerite, only observed in Copris, is the <i>conjunctivus</i>, the
lacinia (prostheca) being well developed. Smith therefore concludes
“that the structure of the mandible is fundamentally the
same as that of the labium and maxilla, and that we have an equally
complex organ in point of origin. Its usual function, however,
demands a powerful and solid structure, and the sclerites are in
most instances as thoroughly chitinized and so closely united to
the others that practically there is only a single piece, in which the
homology is obscured.” (Trans. Amer. Ent. Soc., xix, pp. 84, 85.
1892.) From the studies of Smith and our observations on Staphylinus,
Passalus, Phanæus, etc. (Fig. 50, <i>A</i>, <i>B</i>) we fully agree with
the view that the mandibles are primarily 3–lobed appendages like
the maxillæ. Nymphal Ephemerids have a lacinia-like process.
(Heymons.)</p>

<div  class='figcenter id004'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_62'>62</span>
<img src='images/i_080.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 50.</span>—Mandible of <i>Copris carolina</i>.—After Smith. <i>A</i>′<i>C. anaglypticus</i>. <i>A</i> (figure to right), do. of <i>Leistotrophus cingulatus</i>; <i>B</i>, of <i>Phanæus carnifex</i>; <i>g′</i>, end of galea,—<i>g</i>, enlarged; <i>c</i>, conjunctivus. <i>C</i>, of <i>Meloë angusticollis</i>: <i>l</i>, lacinia; <i>a</i>, lacinia enlarged.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>Mandibles are wanting in the adults of the more specialized Lepidoptera,
being vestigial in the most generalized forms (certain
Tineina and Crambus), but well developed in that very primitive
moth, Eriocephala (Fig. 51). They are also completely atrophied in
the adult Trichoptera, though very large and functional in the pupa
of these insects (Fig. 52), as also in the pupa of Micropteryx (Fig. 53).
They are also wanting in the imago of male Diptera and in the
females of all flies except Culicidæ and Tabanidæ.</p>

<p class='c007'>They are said by Dr. Horn to be absent in the adult <i>Platypsyllus
castoris</i>, though well developed in the larva; and functional mandibles
are lacking in the Hemiptera.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The first maxillæ.</b>—These highly differentiated appendages are
inserted on the sides of the head just behind the mandibles and the
mouth, and are divided into three lobes, or divisions, which are supported
upon two, and sometimes three basal pieces, <i>i.e.</i> the basal
<span class='pageno' id='Page_63'>63</span>joint or <i>cardo</i>, the second joint or <i>stipes</i>, with the <i>palpifer</i>, the latter
present in Termitidæ (Fig. 54, <i>plpgr</i>), but not always separately developed
(Fig. 55). The
cardo varies in shape,
but is more or less triangular
and is usually
wedged in between the
submentum and mandible.
It is succeeded by
the stipes, which usually
forms the support for
the three lobes of the
maxilla, and is more or
less square in shape.</p>

<div  class='figright id033'>
<img src='images/i_081a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 51.</span>—Mandible of <i>Eriocephala calthella</i>: <i>a</i>, <i>a′</i>, inner and outer articulation; <i>s</i>, cavity of the joint (acetabulum); <i>A</i>, end seen from one side of the cutting edge.—After Walter.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id035'>
<img src='images/i_081b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 52.</span>—<i>A</i>, Pupa of <i>Phryganea pilosa</i>.—After Pictet. <i>B</i>, mandibles of pupa of <i>Molanna angustata</i>.—After Sharp.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figcenter id004'>
<img src='images/i_081c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 53.</span>—Pupa of <i>Micropteryx purpuriella</i>, front view: <i>md</i>, mandibles; <i>mx.p</i>, maxillary palpus, end drawn separately; <i>mx.’p</i>, labial palpi; <i>lb</i>, labrum; <i>A</i>, another view from a cast skin.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The three distal divisions
of the maxilla are
called, respectively, beginning with the innermost,
the
<i>lacinia</i>, <i>galea</i>,
and <i>palpifer</i>,
the latter being
a lobe or
segment
bearing the <i>palpus</i>. The lacinia
is more or less jaw-like and
armed on the inner edge with
either flexible or stiff bristles,
spines, or teeth, which are very
variable in shape and are of use
<span class='pageno' id='Page_64'>64</span>as stiff brushes in pollen-eating beetles, etc. The galea is either
single-jointed and helmet-shaped or subspatulate, as in most Orthoptera,
or 2–jointed in Gryllotalpa, or lacinia-like in Myrmeleon
(Fig. 55, <i>C</i>); or, in the Carabidæ (Fig. 56) and Cicindelidæ, it is
2–jointed and in form and function like a palpus.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id008'>
<img src='images/i_082a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 54.</span>—<i>A</i>, maxilla of <i>Termopsis angusticollis</i>. <i>B</i>, <i>Termes flavipes</i>: <i>c</i>, cardo; <i>sti</i>, stipes; <i>plpgr</i>, palpiger; <i>palp</i>, palpus; <i>lac</i>, lacinia; <i>g</i>, <i>gal</i>, galea.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id036'>
<img src='images/i_082b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 55.</span>—<i>A</i>, maxilla of <i>Mantispa brunnea</i>. <i>B</i>, <i>Ascalaphus longicornis</i>. <i>C</i>, <i>Myrmeleon diversum</i>. Lettering as in Fig. 54.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id037'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_65'>65</span>
<img src='images/i_083a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 56.</span>—Maxilla of a carabid, <i>Anophthalmus tellkampfii</i>: <i>l</i>, lacinia; <i>g</i>, 2–jointed galea; <i>p</i>, palpus; <i>st</i>, stipes; <i>c</i>, cardo.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class='section'>

</div>
<div  class='figcenter id038'>
<img src='images/i_083c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 57.</span>—Maxilla of <i>Nemognatha</i>, ♀, from Montana. <i>A</i>, base of maxilla enlarged to show the taste-papillæ (<i>tp</i>) and cups (<i>tc</i>), on the galea (<i>ga</i>). <i>B</i>, part of end of galea to show the imperfect segments and taste-organs: <i>n</i>, nerve; a ganglionated nerve supplies each taste-papilla or cup; <i>l</i>, lacinia; <i>p</i>, palpifer; <i>s</i>, subgalea.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id017'>
<img src='images/i_083b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 58.</span>—Maxilla of Panorpa.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id039'>
<img src='images/i_083d.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 59.</span>—Maxilla of <i>Limnephilus pudicus</i>: <i>mx</i>, stipes; <i>lac</i>, galea.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The palpus is in general antenniform and is composed
of from 1 to 6 joints, being usually 4– or 5–jointed,
and is much longer than the galea. In the maxilla of
the beetle Nemognatha
(Fig. 57), the galea is
greatly elongated,
the two together
forming
an imperfect tube
or proboscis and
reminding one of
the tongue of a
moth, while the
lacinia is reduced. In the Mecoptera the lacinia and
galea are closely similar (Fig. 58); in the
Trichoptera only one of the lobes is present
(Fig. 59), while in the Lepidoptera
the galea unites with its mate to form the
so-called tongue (Fig. 60). The maxilla
of the male of <i>Tegeticula yuccasella</i> is
normal, though the galeæ are separate;
but in the female, what Smith regards as
the palpifer (the “tentacle” of Riley) is
<span class='pageno' id='Page_66'>66</span>remarkably developed, being nearly as long as
the galea (Fig. 61) and armed with stout setæ,
the pair of processes being adapted for holding
a large mass of pollen under the head.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id040'>
<img src='images/i_084a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 60.</span>—Tongue of <i>Aletia xylina</i>, with the end magnified.—Pergande <i>del.</i>, from Riley. <i>A</i>, much reduced maxilla (<i>mx</i>) of <i>Paleacrita vernata</i>; <i>mx.p</i>, palpus.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figcenter id008'>
<img src='images/i_084b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 61.</span>—<i>A</i>, maxilla of <i>Tegeticula yuccasella</i>, ♂: <i>g</i>, galea. <i>B</i>, ♀: <i>pl</i>, enormously developed palpifer; <i>mx.p</i>, palpus; <i>c</i>, cardo; <i>st</i>, stipes; <i>sty</i>, stylus.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In coleopterous larvæ the maxillæ are 2–lobed
<span class='pageno' id='Page_67'>67</span>(Fig. 62), the galea being undifferentiated, but in those of saw-flies
the galea is present (Fig. 63, <i>gal</i>).</p>

<div  class='figright id041'>
<img src='images/i_085.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 62.</span>—Larva of <i>Rhagium lineatum</i>: <i>lat</i>, lateral view of head and thoracic segments; <i>mx</i>, first maxilla; <i>ml</i>, undifferentiated lacinia and galea; <i>v</i>, under side of head and pro- and meso- thoracic segments; <i>v.m.s.</i>, one of the middle ventral segments, magnified six times; <i>mx′</i>, 2d maxilla.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>It now seems most probable that in the first maxillæ we have the
primary form of buccal appendage of insects, the appendage being
composed of three basal pieces with three variously modified distal
lobes or divisions; and that the mandibles and second maxillæ are
modifications of this
type.</p>

<p class='c007'>How wonderfully
the maxillæ of the
Lepidoptera are
modified, and the
peculiar shapes assumed
in the Diptera,
Hymenoptera,
and other groups,
will be stated in the
accounts of those
orders, but it is well
to recall the fact
that in the most
primitive and generalized
moth, Eriocephala,
the lacinia
is well developed
(Fig. 64).</p>

<p class='c007'>As Newport remarks,
the office of
the maxillæ in the
mandibulate insects
is of a twofold
kind; since they are
adapted not only for
seizing and retaining the food in the mouth, but also as accessory
jaws, since they aid the mandibles in comminuting it before it is
passed on to the pharynx and swallowed. Hence, as the food varies
so much in nature and situation, it will be readily seen that the
maxillæ, especially their distal parts, vary correspondingly. Thus
far no close observations on the exact use of the first and second
maxillæ have been published.</p>

<p class='c007'>The palpi also are not only organs of touch, but in some cases
act as hands and also bear minute sense-organs, the function
<span class='pageno' id='Page_68'>68</span>of which is unknown, but would appear to be usually that of
smell.</p>

<div  class='figleft id028'>
<img src='images/i_086a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 63.</span>—<i>Selandria</i> larva, common on <i>Carya porcina</i>, with details of mouth-parts: <i>leg</i>, leg; <i>mx</i>, maxilla; <i>gal</i>, galea; <i>lac</i>, lacinia.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>The second maxillæ.</b>—The “under-lip” or labium of insects is
formed by the fusion at the basal portion of what in the embryo are
separate appendages, and which
arise in the same manner as the
first maxillæ. They are invariably
solidly united, no cases of partial
or incomplete fusion being known.
The so-called labium is situated
in front of the gula or gular region,
and is bounded on each side by
the gena, or cheek. As already
observed, the second maxillæ appear
to be the appendages of the
last or occipital segment of the
head.</p>

<div  class='figright id013'>
<img src='images/i_086b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 64.</span>—Maxilla of <i>Eriocephala calthella</i>: <i>l</i>, lacinia; <i>g</i>, galea; <i>mx.p</i>, maxillary palpus; <i>st</i>, stipes; <i>c</i>, cardo.—After Walter.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The second maxillæ are very
much differentiated
and vary
greatly in the different orders, being especially
modified in the haustellate or suctorial orders,
notably the Hymenoptera and Diptera. In the
mandibulate orders, particularly the Orthoptera,
where they are most generalized and primitive in
shape and structure, they consist of the following
parts: the <i>gula</i> (a <i>postgula</i> is present in Dermaptera),
<i>submentum</i> (lora of Cheshire, i, p. 91), <i>mentum</i>,
<i>palpifer</i>, the latter bearing the <i>palpi</i>; the
<i>lingua</i> (<i>ligula</i>) and <i>paraglossæ</i>, while the hypopharynx
or lingua is situated on the upper side.
The labial palpi are of the same general shape as
those of the first maxillæ, but shorter, with very
rarely more than three joints, though in Pteronarcys
there are four. Leon has detected vestigial
labial palpi in several Hemiptera (Fig. 73). As
to the exact nature and limits of the gula, we
are not certain; it is not always present, and may
be only a differentiation of the submentum, or the
latter piece may be regarded as a part of the gula.</p>

<p class='c007'>We are disposed to consider the second maxillæ as morphologically
nearly the exact equivalents of the first pair of maxillæ, and if we
<span class='pageno' id='Page_69'>69</span>adopt this view it will greatly simplify our conception of the real
nature of this complicated organ. The object of the fusion of the
basal portion appears to be to form an under-lip, in order both to
prevent the food from falling backwards out of the mouth, and, with
the aid of the first pair of maxillæ, to pass it forward to be crushed
between the mandibles, the two sets of appendages acting somewhat
as the tongue of vertebrates to carry and arrange or press the morsels
of food between the teeth or cutting edges of the mandibles.</p>

<p class='c007'>The spines often present on the free inner edges of the first and
second maxillæ (Figs. 54, 62) form rude combs which seem to clean
the antennæ, etc., often aiding the tibial combs in this operation.</p>

<p class='c007'>The submentum and mentum, or the mentum when no submentum
is differentiated (with the gula, when present), appear to be collectively
homologous with the cardines of the first pair of maxillæ, together
with the palpifers and the stipites.<a id='r15' /><a href='#f15' class='c012'><sup>[15]</sup></a> These pieces are more or
less square, and have a slightly marked median suture in Termitidæ,
the sign of primitive fusion or coalescence.</p>

<p class='c007'>The most primitive form of the second maxillæ occurs in the Orthoptera
and in the Termitidæ. The palpifer is either single (Periplaneta,
Diapheromera, Gryllidæ) or double (<i>Blatta orientalis</i>, Locustidæ).
In Prisopus the single piece in front of the palpifer is in other
forms divided, each half (Blatta, Locustidæ, Acrydidæ) bearing the
two “paraglossæ,” which appendages in reality are the homologues
of the lacinia and galea of the first maxillæ.<a id='r16' /><a href='#f16' class='c012'><sup>[16]</sup></a> In the Termitidæ (Fig.
65) the lingua is not differentiated from the palpifer, and the two
paraglossæ (or the lamina externa and interna of some authors)
with the palpus are easily seen to be the homologues of the three
lobes of the first maxillæ. In the Perlidæ (Pteronarcys, Fig. 66)
the palpifer is divided, while the four paraglossæ arise, as in Prisopus
and Anisomorpha, from an undivided piece, the lingua not being
visible from without. In the Neuroptera the lingua or ligula is a
large, broad, single lobe, without “paraglossæ,” and the palpifer is
either single (Myrmeleon, Fig. 67), or divided (Mantispa, Fig. 68).
<span class='pageno' id='Page_70'>70</span>In Corydalus (Fig. 29) the palpifer forms a single piece, and the
lingua is undivided, though lobed on the free edge.</p>

<div  class='figleft id024'>
<img src='images/i_088a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 65.</span>—Second maxillæ  of <i>Termopsis angusticollis</i>: <i>li</i>, the homologue of the lacinia; <i>le</i>, galea.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the metabolic orders above the Neuroptera the lingua is variously
modified, or specialized, with no vestiges of the lacinia or
galea, except in that very primitive
moth, Eriocephala, in which Walter
found a minute free galea, <i>me</i>, and an
inner lobe (Figs. 76, 77), the lacinia.</p>

<div  class='figright id013'>
<img src='images/i_088b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 66.</span>—Second maxillæ of <i>Pteronarcys californica</i>.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id010'>
<img src='images/i_088c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 67.</span>—Second maxillæ of <i>Myrmeleon diversum</i>.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id017'>
<img src='images/i_088d.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 68.</span>—Second maxillæ of <i>Mantispa brunnea</i>.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>The hypopharynx.</b>—While in its most
generalized condition, as in Synaptera,
Dermaptera, Orthoptera, and Neuroptera,
this anterior median fold or outgrowth
of the labium forming the floor
of the mouth may retain the designation
of “tongue,” lingua, or ligula; in its
more specialized form, particularly when
used as a piercing or lapping organ, the
use of the name <i>hypopharynx</i> seems most
desirable. And this is especially the
case since, like the epipharynx, it is
morphologically a median structure, and
while the epipharynx forms the soft,
sensitive roof of the mouth, or pharynx;
its opposite, the hypopharynx, rises as
a fold from the floor of the mouth, forming
in its most generalized condition a specialized fold of the buccal
integument. In certain cases, as in the honey-bee, the very long
slender “tongue” or hypopharynx is evidently, as in the case of
the epipharynx, a highly sensitive armature of the mouth.</p>

<p class='c007'><span class='pageno' id='Page_71'>71</span>In all insects this organ—whether forming a soft, tongue-like,
anterior portion or fold of the labium, and “continuous with the
lower wall of the pharynx,” or a hard, piercing, awl-like appendage
(fleas and flies), or a long, slender, hairy or setose, trough-like structure
like the “tongue” of the honey-bee—has a definite location at
the end and on the upper side of the labium, and serves to receive
at its base the external opening of the salivary duct.</p>

<p class='c007'>The hypopharynx, as well shown in its lingua condition in Orthoptera,
is continuous with and forms the anterior part or fold of
the base of the coalesced second maxillæ. It does not seem to be
paired, or to represent a pair of appendages.</p>

<p class='c007'>Opinion regarding the homology of this unpaired piercing organ
is by no means settled, and while there is a general agreement as to
the nature of the paired mouth-parts, recent observers differ very
much as to the morphology of the organ in question.</p>

<p class='c007'>It is the langue or <i>lingua</i> of Savigny (1816), the <i>ligula</i> of Kirby
and Spence (1828), the <i>langue ou languette</i> (<i>lancette médiane du suçoir</i>)
of Dugès (1832), the <i>lingua</i> of Westwood (Class, ins., ii, p. 489, 1840),
“the unpaired median piercing organ” (“the analogon of the epipharynx
of Diptera”) of Karsten (1864), the “tongue” of Taschenberg
(1880).</p>

<p class='c007'>The name <i>hypopharynx</i> was first proposed by Savigny in 1816,
who, after naming the membranous plate which has for its base the
upper side of the pharynx, the <i>epipharynx</i>, remarks: “<span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Dans quelques
genres, notamment dans les Eucères, le bord inférieur de ce même
pharynx donne naissance à un autre appendice plus solide que le
précédent, et qui s’emboîte avec lui. Je donnerai à ce dernier le
nom de <i>langue</i> ou d’<i>hypopharynx</i>. Voilà donc la bouche des Hyménoptères
composée de quatre organes impaires, sans y comprendre la
ganache ou le menton; savoir, la lèvre supérieure, l’épipharynx,
l’hypopharynx, et la lèvre inférieure, et de deux organes paires, les
mandibules et les mâchoires.</span>”</p>

<p class='c007'>As stated by Dimmock: “The hypopharynx is usually present in
Diptera (according to Menzbier absent in Sargus), and contains a tube,
opening by a channel on its upper surface; this channel extends
back, more or less, from the tip, and is the outlet for the salivary
secretion. The tip of the hypopharynx may be naked and used as
a lance (Hæmatopota, according to Menzbier), or may be hairy
(Musca). The upper side of the base of the hypopharynx is
continuous with the lower wall of the pharynx; its under surface
may entirely coalesce with the labium (Culex, male), may join
the labium more or less, anterior to the month (Musca), or, if
<span class='pageno' id='Page_72'>72</span>either mandibles or maxillæ are present, its base may join them
(Culex, female).” (p. 43.)</p>

<div  class='figleft id024'>
<img src='images/i_090a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 69.</span>—Section of head of <i>Machilis maritima</i>: <i>hyp</i>, hypopharynx; <i>lbr</i>, labrum; <i>t</i>, tentorium; <i>ph</i>, room in which the mandibles move on each other; <i>p</i>, paraglossa; <i>mx</i>, labium; <i>sd</i>, salivary duct; <i>s.gl</i>, salivary gland. <i>oe</i>, œsophagus.—After Oudemans.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>We will now briefly describe the lingua, first of the mandibulate
or biting insects, and then its specialized form, the hypopharynx of
the haustellate and lapping insects.</p>

<p class='c007'>The lingua (hypopharynx) exists in
perhaps its most generalized condition
in the Thysanura (Fig. 69), where it
forms a soft projection, having the same
relations as in Anabrus and other Orthoptera.<a id='r17' /><a href='#f17' class='c012'><sup>[17]</sup></a></p>

<p class='c007'>In the cockroach (Fig. 70), as stated
by Miall and Denny, the lingua is a
chitinous fold of the oral integument
situated in front of the labium, and lying
in the cavity of the mouth. The
common duct of the salivary glands
enters the lingua, and opens on its
hinder surface. The lingua is supported
by a chitinous skeleton (Figs. 70, <i>B</i>; 82,
<i>shp</i>). “The thin chitinous surface of the
lingua is hairy, like other parts of the
mouth, and stiffened by special chitinous rods or bands.” (Miall
and Denny.)</p>

<div  class='figright id010'>
<img src='images/i_090b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 70.</span>—Hypopharynx of <i>Periplaneta orientalis</i>; the arrow points out of the opening of the salivary duct: <i>A</i>, origin of salivary duct. <i>B</i>, side view. <i>C</i>, front view.—After Miall and Denny.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the Acrydiidæ (<i>Melanoplus femur-rubrum</i>) the tongue is a large,
membranous, partly hollow
expansion of the base of the
labium. It may be exposed
by depressing the end of the
labium, when the opening of
the salivary duct may be seen
at the bottom or end of the
space or gap between the
hinder base of the tongue,
and the inner anterior base of
the labium, as shown by the
arrows in Fig. 70. It is somewhat pyriform, slightly keeled above,
and bearing fine stiff bristles, which, as they point more or less
inwards, probably aid in retaining the food within the mouth. The
<span class='pageno' id='Page_73'>73</span>base of the tongue is narrow, and extends back to near the pharynx,
there being on the floor of the mouth, behind the tongue, two oblique,
slight ridges, covered with stiff, golden-yellow hairs, like those on
the tongue. The opening of the salivary duct is situated on the
under or hinder side of the hypopharynx,
between it and the base of the labium, the
base of the former being cleft; the hollow
thus formed is situated over the opening,
and forms the salivary receptacle.</p>

<div  class='figleft id014'>
<img src='images/i_091a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 71.</span>—Section through the anterior part of the head of Anabrus (the mandibles removed), showing the relations of the hypopharynx (<i>hyp</i>) to the opening of the salivary duct (<i>sd</i>): <i>g</i>, galea; <i>l</i>, lacinia; <i>mt</i>, mentum; <i>oe</i>, œsophagus; <i>lbr</i>, labrum; <i>cl</i>, clypeus.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the Locustidæ (Anabrus, Fig. 71) the
tongue (hypopharynx) is a broad, somewhat
flattened lobe arising from the upper
part of the base of the mentum and behind
the palpifer. This lobe is cavernous underneath,
the hollow being the salivary
receptacle (<i>sr</i>); the latter is situated over
the opening of the salivary duct, which is
placed between the base of both the hypopharynx
and the labium. The salivary
fluid apparently has to pass up and around on each side of the hypopharynx
in order to mix with the food.</p>

<p class='c007'>These relations in the Orthoptera are also the same in the
Perlidæ, where the hypopharynx is well developed, forming an
unusually large tongue-like mass, nearly filling the buccal cavity.</p>

<div  class='figright id042'>
<img src='images/i_091b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 72.</span>—Lingua of a May-fly, <i>Heptagenia longicauda</i>, ×16: <i>m</i>, central; <i>l</i>, lateral pieces.—After Vayssière from Sharp.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the Odonata the lingua is a small, rounded lobe, as also in the
Ephemeridæ; in the nymph, however, of Heptagenia (Fig. 72) it is
highly developed, according
to Vayssière, who seems inclined
to regard it as representing
a pair of appendages.
The tongue in Hemiptera is
said by Léon to be present in
<i>Benacus griseus</i> (Say) and to
correspond to the subgalea of
Brullé or hypodactyle of Audouin
(Fig. 73), but this appears
to correspond to the labium proper, rather than a true lingua,
the latter not being differentiated in this order. In the Coleoptera
the lingua is rather small. In beetles, as Anopthalmus (Fig. 74), it
forms a setose lobe; and a well-developed nerve, the lingual nerve,
passes to it, dividing at the end into several branches (<i>n-l</i>). In Sialis
the lingua is short, much less developed than usual, being rounded,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_74'>74</span>and bears on the edge what appear to be numerous taste-hairs, like
those on the ends of the maxillary and labial palpi.</p>

<div  class='figleft id028'>
<img src='images/i_092a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 73.</span>—<i>A</i>, labium of <i>Zaitha anura</i>. <i>B</i>, of <i>Z. margineguttata</i>. <i>C</i>, of <i>Gerris najas</i>: <i>mt</i>, mentum; <i>lp</i>, labial palpi; <i>sg</i>, subgalea; <i>l</i>, lacinia (= intermaxillare and præmaxillare of Brullé); <i>g</i>, galea.—After Léon.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the adult Panorpidæ the
lingua is a minute, simple lobe.</p>

<div  class='figright id043'>
<img src='images/i_092b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 74.</span>—Section through head of a carabid, <i>Anopthalmus telkampfii</i>: <i>br</i>, brain; <i>f. g</i>, frontal ganglion; <i>soe</i>, subœsophageal ganglion; <i>co</i>, commissure; <i>n. l</i>, nerve sending branches to the lingua (<i>l</i>); <i>mn</i>, maxillary nerve; <i>mx</i>, 1st maxilla; <i>mm</i>, maxillary muscle; <i>mx′</i>, 2d maxilla; <i>mt</i>, muscle of mentum; <i>le</i>, elevator muscle of the œsophagus; <i>l</i> of the clypeus, and a third beyond raising the labrum (<i>lbr</i>); <i>eph</i>, epipharynx; <i>g</i>, <i>g</i>, salivary glands above; <i>g</i><sup>2</sup>, lingual gland below the œsophagus (<i>oe</i>); <i>m</i>, mouth; <i>pv</i>, proventriculus; <i>md</i>, mandible. <i>A</i>, section passing through lingual gland (<i>g</i><sup>2</sup>).</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the larval Trichoptera the
spinneret is well developed, and
in structure substantially like
that of caterpillars, and it is
plainly the homologue of the
hypopharynx, receiving as it
does the end of the silk-duct.</p>

<p class='c007'>In the adult Trichoptera the
hypopharynx is a very large,
tongue-like, fleshy outgrowth,
and is, both in situation and
structure, since
it contains the
opening of the
silk-duct, exactly
homologous
with the hypopharynx
of insects
of other
orders, being somewhat intermediate
between the fleshy
tongue or lingua of the mandibulate
insects, especially the
<span class='pageno' id='Page_75'>75</span>Neuroptera, and the hypopharynx of the bees (Fig. 86). Lucas
describes and figures it under the name of “haustellum,” but does
not homologize it with the hypopharynx. The caddis-flies have been
observed to drink water and take in both fluid and fine particles
of solid food, and to use the haustellum
for this purpose, the end being provided
with minute sense-organs like
those on the first maxillary lacinia, and
possibly of a gustatory nature.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id004'>
<img src='images/i_093a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 75.</span>—Head of <i>Anabolia furcata</i>: <i>A</i>, front view, showing the labrum removed. <i>B</i>, side view; <i>ant</i>, antenna; <i>oc</i>, ocellus; <i>ol</i>, labrum; <i>gh</i>, articulatory process; <i>cmx</i><sub>1</sub>, cardo; <i>stmx</i><sub>1</sub>, stipes; <i>lemx</i><sub>1</sub>, outer lobe (galea); <i>ptmx</i><sub>1</sub>, palpus of 1st maxilla; <i>pl</i>, palpus of 2d maxilla; <i>ha</i>, haustellum; <i>so</i>, gustatory pits; <i>spr</i>, opening of salivary duct; <i>chsp</i>, chitinous hook of the clasp; <i>spr</i>, furrow or gutter of the haustellum.—After Lucas.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id023'>
<img src='images/i_093b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 76.</span>—Hypopharynx of <i>Eriocephala calthella</i>: <i>lig</i>, ligula, its membranous hinder edge; <i>lig′</i>, anterior horny edge of the ligula-tube opening outwards; <i>hp</i>, contour of the hypopharynx; <i>mi</i>, mala interior (lacinia); <i>me</i>, mala exterior (galea), of second maxilla; <i>mx′ p</i>, labial palpus.—After Walter.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The spinneret of the larvæ of Lepidoptera
is evidently the homologue of
the hypopharynx of insects of other
orders. It will be seen that the homology
of the different parts is identical,
the common duct of the silk-glands
opening at the end of the hypopharynx,
which here forms a complete
tube or proboscis extending beyond the
end of the labium, in adaptation to its
use as a spinning organ.</p>

<p class='c007'>Walter refers to Burgess’s discovery
of a hypopharynx in <i>Danais archippus</i>,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_76'>76</span>remarking that this organ in the adult Eriocephalidæ (Fig. 76)
exhibits a great similarity to the relations observable in the lower
insects, adding:—</p>

<div  class='figright id020'>
<img src='images/i_094a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 77.</span>— Labium of <i>Micropteryx anderschella</i> seen from within (the labial palpi (<i>mx.′ p</i>) removed to their basal joint). Lettering as in Fig. 76.—After Walter.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>“The furrow is here within coalesced with the inner side of the
labium, and though I see in the entire structure of the head the
inner edge of the ligula tube
extended under the epipharynx
as far as the mandible, I must
also accept the fact that here
also the hypopharynx extends to
the mouth-opening as in all other
sucking insects with a well-developed
under-lip, viz. the Diptera
and Hymenoptera.”</p>

<p class='c007'>He has also discovered in
Micropteryx a paired structure
which he regards as the hypopharynx
(Fig. 77). As he states:</p>

<div  class='figleft id007'>
<img src='images/i_094b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 78.</span>—Hypopharynx (<i>hph</i>) of Danais: <i>cl</i>, clypeus; <i>sd</i>, salivary duct; <i>m</i>, labial palp muscles; <i>fm</i>, frontal muscle; <i>ph</i>, pharynx; <i>cor</i>, cornea.—After Burgess.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>“A portion of the inner surface
of the tube-like ligula is
covered by a furrow-like band which, close to the inner side, is
coalesced with it, and in position, shape, as well as its appendages
or teeth on the edge, may be
regarded as nothing else than
the hypopharynx.”</p>

<p class='c007'>A hypopharynx is also present
in the highest Lepidoptera,
Burgess having detected it in
<i>Danais archippus</i>. He states
that the hypopharynx forms
the floor of the pharyngeal
cavity; “it is convex on each
side of a median furrow (Fig.
78, <i>hph</i>) and somewhat resembles
in shape the human breast.
The convex areas are dotted over with little papillæ, which possibly
may be taste-organs.”</p>

<p class='c007'>As a piercing organ the hypopharynx reaches its greatest development
in the Siphonaptera and Diptera, where the chitinous parts are
greatly hypertrophied, the fleshy tongue-like portion so developed in
the mandibulate orders being greatly reduced. The chitinous parts are
alike on each side of the median organ, being bilaterally symmetrical.</p>

<div  class='figleft id020'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_77'>77</span>
<img src='images/i_095a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 79.</span>—<i>A</i>, hypopharynx of <i>Pulex canis</i>: <i>x</i>, basal portion situated within the head; <i>s. d</i>, common duct of the four bladder-shaped salivary glands; <i>s. d′</i>, opening of the tubular salivary glands into the throat. <i>B</i>, end of the hypopharynx, showing the gutter-like structure and teeth at the end.—After Landois.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id007'>
<img src='images/i_095b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 80.</span>—Beak of Vermipsylla: <i>hyp</i>, hypopharynx.—After Wagner.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the fleas the hypopharynx is a large, slender, unpaired, long,
chitinous trough, as long as the mandibles, and toothed at the end.
Figures 79 and 80 show its relations to the other parts of the mouth;
in Fig. 79, <i>x</i>, is seen where the salivary duct opens into the pharynx.
Although this organ is not unanimously referred to the hypopharynx,
yet from the description of Landois and others, it is evident that
this structure does not correspond to the labrum or epipharynx, but
belongs to or arises from the floor of the mouth, and, being in close
relation to the labium, and also receiving the salivary duct, must be
a true hypopharynx.</p>

<p class='c007'><span class='pageno' id='Page_78'>78</span>In the Diptera the hypopharynx reaches its highest development
as a large, stout, awl-like structure.</p>

<p class='c007'>Meinert, in his detailed and elaborately illustrated work, Trophi
Dipterorum (1881), has made an advance on our knowledge of the
hypopharynx and its homologies, both by his evidently faithful descriptions
and dissections, and by his admirably clear figures.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id040'>
<img src='images/i_096a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 81.</span>—<i>Culex pipiens</i>, section of head: <i>oe</i> œsophagus; <i>sm</i>, upper muscle, <i>lm</i>, lower muscle of the œsophagus; <i>ph</i>, pharynx; <i>rm</i>, retractor muscle of the receptacle (<i>r</i>) of the salivary duct (<i>s.d</i>); <i>lbr</i>, labrum; <i>ep</i>, left style of the epipharynx; <i>f</i>, part of front of head.—After Meinert.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id030'>
<img src='images/i_096b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 82.</span>—Pharynx and hypopharynx of <i>Simulium fuscipes</i>: <i>lph</i>, lower lamina of the pharynx; <i>p</i>, the salivary duct (<i>s.d</i>) perforating the pharynx; <i>o</i>, orifice of the duct; <i>shp</i>, styles of the hypopharynx; <i>mph</i>, membranous edge of the hypopharynx; <i>m</i>, protractor muscle of the pharynx; <i>gp</i>, gustatory papillæ.—After Meinert.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>“The hypopharynx, a continuation of the lower
edge (<i>lamina</i>) of the pharynx, most generally free,
more or less produced, acute anteriorly, forms with
the labrum the tube of the pump (<i>antliæ</i>). (The hypopharynx
when obsolete, or coalesced with the canal of
the proboscis, is the <i>theca</i>; in such a case the siphon
or tube is formed by the theca and labrum.) Meanwhile
the hypopharynx, the largest of all the trophi
(<i>omnium trophorum maximus</i>), constitutes the chief
piercing organ (<i>telum</i>) of Diptera. The hypopharynx
is moved by protractor, most generally quite or very
powerful, and by retractor muscles.</p>

<p class='c013'>“The efferent duct of the thoracic salivary glands
(<i>ductus salivalis</i>) perforates the hypopharynx, more
or less near the base, that the saliva may be ejected
through the canal into the wound, or that it may be
conducted along the labella. Very rarely the salivary
duct, perforating the hypopharynx, is continued in
the shape of a free, very slender tube.</p>

<p class='c013'>“The salivary duct behind the base of the hypopharynx
forms the receptacle or <i>receptaculum</i>, provided
with retractor and levator muscles.”</p>

<div  class='figcenter id044'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_79'>79</span>
<img src='images/i_097a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 83.</span>—Labrum-epipharynx (<i>lbr</i> and <i>eph</i>) and hypopharynx (<i>hyp</i>) of <i>Tabanus brominus</i>: <i>oe</i>, posterior cylindrical portion of the œsophagus; <i>a</i>, anterior swollen portion of the same; <i>ph</i>, pharynx; <i>ph.m</i>, pharyngeal muscle; <i>p.ph</i>, protractor muscle of the pharynx; <i>r.oe</i>, retractor muscle of the œsophagus; <i>r.ph</i>, retractor muscle of the pharynx; <i>f.oe</i>, flexor muscle of the pharynx; <i>t.oe</i>, twisting muscle of the œsophagus; <i>s.r</i>, receptacle of the salivary duct; <i>l</i>, its elevator muscle; <i>s</i>, its retractor muscle; <i>cl</i>, clypeus.—After Meinert.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figcenter id045'>
<img src='images/i_097b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 84.</span>—Œsophagus (<i>oe</i>), pharynx (<i>ph</i>) with epipharynx and labrum (<i>lbr</i>) of <i>Asilus atricapillus</i>: <i>m</i>, <i>ph</i>, pharyngeal muscle; <i>sr</i>, salivary receptacle; <i>t</i>, twisting; <i>r</i>, <i>l′r</i>, retractor muscles; other lettering as in Fig. 83.—After Meinert.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>It has been carefully studied by Meinert in
a species of Culex (Fig. 81), Simulium (Fig.
82), Tabanus (Fig. 83), and in Asilus (Fig. 84),
where it is seen to attain enormous proportions. In the Hymenoptera,
this organ in its most specialized condition is a trough-like
rod, adapted for lapping nectar (Fig. 85, 86, <i>hyp</i>). The
tongue or hypopharynx of the honey-bee has been elaborately described
by Cheshire in his Bees and Bee Keeping.<a id='r18' /><a href='#f18' class='c012'><sup>[18]</sup></a> He calls it
the tongue or ligula. It is situated in a tube formed by the maxillæ
and labial palpi, and can be partially retracted into the mentum.
He states that it can move up and down in the tube thus formed,
and then describes it as covered by a hairy sheath, its great elasticity
being due to a rod running through its centre enabling it to be used
as a lapping tongue. The sheath</p>

<p class='c013'><span class='pageno' id='Page_80'>80</span>“passes round the tongue to the back, where its edges do not meet, but are
continuous with a very thin plaited membrane (<i>G</i>, <i>pm</i>) covered with minute hairs.
This membrane, after passing towards the sides of the tongue, returns to the
angle of the nucleus, or rod, over the under surface of which it is probably continued.
The rod passes through the tongue from end to end, gradually tapering
towards its extremity, and is best studied in the queen, where I trace many
nerve threads and cells.
It is undoubtedly endowed
with voluntary
movement, and must
be partly muscular,
although I have failed
completely in getting
any evidence of striation.
The rod on the
underside has a gutter,
or trough-like hollow
(<i>cd</i>, the central duct)
which is formed into a
pseudotube (false tube)
by intercrossing of
black hairs. It will
also be seen that, by
the posterior meeting
of the sheath, the space
between the folded
membrane (<i>G</i>, <i>sd</i>) becomes
two pseudotubes
of larger size, which I
shall call the side ducts.</p>

<div  class='figleft id041'>
<img src='images/i_098.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 85.</span>—Head of honey bee, worker: <i>a</i>, antenna; <i>g</i>, epipharynx; <i>m</i>, mandible; <i>mx</i>, maxilla; <i>mxp</i>, maxillary palpus; <i>pg</i>, paraglossa; <i>lp</i>, labial palpus; <i>l</i>, hypopharynx; <i>b</i>, its spoon.—After Cheshire; from Bull. Div. Ent. U. S. Dept. Agr.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>“These central and
side ducts run down to
that part of the tongue
where the spoon, or
bouton (<i>K</i>, Fig. 86)
is placed. This is provided
with very delicate
split hairs (<i>b</i>, Fig. 86)
capable of brushing up
the most minute quantity
of nectar, which by
capillarity is at once
transferred by the gathering
hairs (which are
here numerous, long,
and thin) to two side groove-like forms at the back of the bouton, and which
are really the opened-out extremity of the centre and side ducts, assuming,
immediately above the bouton, the form seen in <i>F</i>, Fig. 86. The central duct,
which is only from <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>600</span></span> inch to <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>1000</span></span> inch in diameter, because of its smaller
size, and so greater capillary attraction, receives the nectar, if insufficient in
quantity to fill the side ducts. But good honey-yielding plants would bring both
centre and side ducts into requisition. The nectar is sucked up until it reaches
the paraglossæ (<i>pa</i>, <i>B</i>, Fig. 86), which are plate-like in front, but membranous
extensions, like small aprons, behind; and by these the nectar reaches the front
of the tongue, to be swallowed as before described.”</p>

<div  class='figcenter id046'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_81'>81</span>
<img src='images/i_099.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 86.</span>—Tongue or ligula of the honey bee: <i>A</i>, under side of the tongue; <i>lp</i>, labial palpi; <i>r</i>, <i>r</i>, rod; <i>p</i>, pouch; <i>sh</i>, sheath; <i>gh</i>, gathering hairs; <i>b</i>, bouton or spoon. <i>B</i>, under lip or labium, with appendages, partly dissected; <i>l</i>, lora or submentum; <i>a</i>, <i>a</i>, retractor linguæ longus; <i>sd</i>, salivary duct; <i>rb</i> and <i>b</i>, retractor linguæ biceps; <i>mx</i>, maxillæ; <i>lp</i>, labial palpi; <i>pa</i>, paraglossa; <i>gr</i>, feeding groove; <i>sh</i>, sheath of ligula. <i>C</i>, <i>D</i>, <i>E</i>, sections of ligula; <i>hp</i>, hyaline plate of maxilla; <i>h</i>, hairs acting as stops; <i>mx</i>, maxilla; <i>lp</i>, labial palpi; <i>sd</i>, side duct. <i>F</i>, cross-section of extremity of tongue near the “spoon”; <i>th</i>, tactile hairs; <i>r</i>, rod; <i>n</i>, nucleus; <i>gh</i>, gathering hairs. <i>G</i>, cross-section of tongue without gathering hairs, × 400 times; <i>sh</i>,
sheath; <i>b</i>, blood space; <i>t</i>, trachea: <i>ng</i>, gustatory nerve; <i>cd</i>, central duct; <i>sd</i>, lateral duct; <i>pm</i>, plaited membrane. <i>H</i>, same as <i>G</i>, but magnified two hundred times, and with <i>pm</i>, plaited membrane, turned outwards; <i>h</i>, closing hairs; <i>lp</i>, labial palpi; <i>b</i>, blood; <i>n</i>, nucleus; <i>r</i>, rod; <i>h</i>, closing hairs. <i>I</i>, small portion of the sheath; lettering as before. <i>K</i>, extremity of the tongue, with spoon; <i>b</i>, branching hairs for gathering.—After Cheshire.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><span class='pageno' id='Page_82'>82</span>Cheshire then settles the question which has been in dispute since
the time of Swammerdam, whether the bee’s tongue is solid or tubular.
He agrees with Wolff that the duct is a trough and not a
tube, and proves it by a satisfactory experiment. He remarks:</p>

<div  class='figcenter id015'>
<img src='images/i_100.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 87.</span>—Longitudinal section through the head of the honey bee, ♀, just outside of right antenna: <i>ant</i>, antenna with three muscles attached to <i>mes</i>, mesocephalic pillar; <i>cl</i>, clypeus; <i>lbr</i>, labrum; 1, chyle-gland (system no. 1, of Siebold); <i>o</i>, opening of the same; <i>oc</i>, ocellus; <i>br</i>, brain; <i>n</i>, neck; <i>th</i>, thorax; <i>oe</i>, œsophagus; <i>s.d</i><sup>2</sup>, <i>s.d</i><sup>3</sup>, common salivary ducts of systems 2 and 3; <i>v</i>, salivary valve; <i>c</i>, cardo; <i>ph</i>, pharynx; <i>mx′</i>, labium; <i>mx.′p</i>, labial palpi; <i>mt</i>, mentum; <i>mx</i>, maxilla; <i>hyp</i>, hypopharynx; <i>s</i>, bouton.—After Cheshire.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>“Bees have the power, by driving blood into the tongue, of forcing the rod
out from the sheath, and distending the wrinkled membrane so that in section
it appears as at <i>H</i>, Fig. 86, the membrane assuming the form of a pouch, given
in full length at <i>A</i>. It will be seen at once that this disposition of parts abolishes
the side ducts, but brings the central duct to the external surface. The
object of this curious capability on the part of the bee is, in my opinion, to
permit of cleaning away any pollen grains, or other impediment that may collect
in the side ducts. The membrane is greasy in nature, and substances or fluids
can be removed from it as easily as water from polished metal. If, now, the
sides of a needle, previously dipped into clove oil in which rosanilin (magenta)
has been dissolved, so as to stain it strongly red, be touched on the centre of
the rod, the oil immediately enters, and passes rapidly upwards and downwards,
filling the trough.”</p>

<p class='c013'><b>Does the hypopharynx represent a distinct segment?</b>—The facts which
suggest that the hypopharynx may possibly represent a highly modified pair of
appendages, arising from a distinct intermaxillary segment, are these: Heymons
plainly shows that, in the embryo of Lepisma, the hypopharynx originates as a
transverse segment-like fold in front of the 2d maxillary segment, and larger
than it, and though he does not mention it in his text, it appears like the rudiment
of a distinct segment; the hypopharynx of Ephemeridæ; arises and remains
separate in the nymph from the labium (see Heymons’ Fig. 29, and there are
two lateral projections; see also Fig. 72, and Vayssiere’s view that it may
represent a pair of appendages; Kolbe also regards it as representing a third
pair of maxillæ, his endolabium, p. 213). Though what is called an unpaired
<span class='pageno' id='Page_83'>83</span>organ, it is composed of, or supported by, two bilaterally symmetrical styles,
both in Myriopods (Fig. 6, labiella, <i>stil</i>) and in insects (Fig. 77, etc.). On the
other hand, in the embryo of pterygote insects, an intermaxillary segment has
not been yet detected.</p>

<h3 class='c002'>LITERATURE OF THE MOUTH-PARTS OR BUCCAL APPENDAGES</h3>

1<sup>re</sup>. Mém. 1–2. Théorie des organes de la bouche des crustacés et des insectes.
12 Pl., Paris, 1816, pp. 1–117.</span></p>
