<div>
  <span class='pageno' id='Page_222'>222</span>
  <h3 class='c002'>THE NERVOUS SYSTEM</h3>
</div>

<h4 class='c011'><i>a.</i> The nervous system as a whole</h4>

<div  class='figcenter id076'>
<img src='images/i_240.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 239.</span>—Central nervous system of <i>Machilis maritima</i>: <i>au</i>, eye; <i>lo</i>, optic tract; <i>g</i>, brain; <i>an</i>, antennal nerve; <i>oe</i>, œsophagus passing between the œsophageal commissures; <i>usg</i>, infraœsophageal ganglion; I-III, thoracic ganglia; 1–8, abdominal ganglia, the last (<i>Sabc</i>) consisting of three fused ganglia; <i>s</i>, sympathetic nervous system of the ventral cord.—After Oudemans, from Lang.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c016'>The nervous system of insects consists
of a double series or chain of ganglia connected
by nervous cords or commissures.
The first of these is the brain or supraœsophageal
ganglion; it is situated in the
upper part of the head, above the gullet
or œsophagus, while the rest of the system,
called the ventral cord, lies on the
floor of the body, under the digestive
canal.</p>

<p class='c007'>A ganglion or nerve-centre consists of
a mass of ganglion-cells, from each of
which a process or fibre passes off, uniting
with others to form a nerve; by means of
these nerves the ganglia are connected
with other ganglia, and with the sensory
cells and muscle-fibres. The ganglia may
be simple, and arranged in pairs, corresponding
to each segment of the body,
or they may be compound, the result of
the fusion of several pairs of ganglia,
which in the early stages of the embryo
are separate. Thus the brain of insects
is a compound ganglion, or ganglionic
mass.</p>

<p class='c007'>The nerves are of two kinds: 1. <i>Sensory</i>,
which transmit sensations from the
peripheral sense-cells to the ganglion, or
brain; 2. <i>Motor</i>, which send stimuli from
the brain or any other ganglion to the
muscles.</p>

<p class='c007'>Of ganglion cells, some are tactile, and
others give rise to nerves of special sense,
being distributed to the eyes, or to the
organs of hearing, smell, taste, or touch.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id077'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_223'>223</span>
<img src='images/i_241a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 240.</span>—Nervous system of <i>Melanoplus spretus</i>: <i>sp</i>, supraœsophageal ganglion, sending off the large optic nerve (<i>op</i>) to the eyes, and  an ocellar nerve to each ocellus (the dotted line <i>oc</i> stops short of the left ocellus); <i>if</i>, infraœsophageal ganglion; 1, 2, 3, thoracic ganglia; 1–5, five abdominal ganglia (the fifth the largest, and sending branches to the ovipositor, etc.) The sympathetic nerve and ganglia are represented by the two main nerves which arise from the medio-cephalic (<i>as</i>) resting on and above the œsophagus, and two ganglia (<i>ps</i>) on the under side of the crop. From each of these ganglia, two nerves are sent under the crop, and a larger nerve on each side to as far as the stomachal cæca, ending the figure at the dotted line 2, near the second thoracic ganglion. <i>u</i>, a round, shining body, connected by a nerve with the medio-cephalic ganglion, its nature unknown.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id024'>
<img src='images/i_241b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 241.</span>—Section through the head of Machilis, showing the brain (<i>br</i>), and subœsophageal ganglion (<i>soe. g</i>); <i>cl</i>, clypeus; <i>lbr</i>, labrum; <i>oc</i>, ocellus.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>While the supraœsophageal ganglion,
or “brain,” of the insect is much more
complex than any other ganglion, consisting more exclusively both of sensory as well as motor ganglia and
their nerves, it should be borne in mind that the subœsophageal
ganglion also receives nerves of special sense, situated on the palpi
and on the tongue, as in the bee
and other insects; hence this
ganglion is probably complex,
consisting of sensory and motor
cells. The third thoracic ganglion
is also, without doubt, a
complex one, as in the locusts
the auditory nerves pass into it
from the ears, which are situated
at the base of the abdomen, while
in the green grasshoppers, such
as the katydids and their allies,
whose ears are situated in their
fore legs, the first thoracic ganglion
is a complex one. In the
cockroach and in Leptis (Chrysopila),
a common fly, the caudal
appendages bear what are probably
olfactory organs, and as
these parts are undoubtedly supplied from the last abdominal ganglion,
this is probably composed of sensory and motor ganglia; so
that we have in the ganglionated cord of insects a series of brains, as
it were, running from head to tail, and thus in a still stronger sense
<span class='pageno' id='Page_224'>224</span>than in vertebrates the entire nervous system, and not the brain
alone, is the organ of the mind of insects.</p>

<p class='c007'>The simplest, most primitive form of the nervous system of insects
is seen in that of the Thysanura. That of Campodea has not yet
been fully examined, but in that of the more complicated genus,
Machilis (Fig. 239), we see that there is a pair of ganglia to nearly
each segment, while the brain (Fig. 241) is composed of three lobes,
viz. the optic, the cerebral (Fig. 239, <i>g</i>), behind which is the antennal
lobe, from which the antennal nerve takes its origin. Behind the
opening for the throat (<i>oe</i>) is situated the first ganglion of the
ventral cord, the subœsophageal ganglion, which gives rise to
the nerves supplying the jaws and other mouth-parts.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id078'>
<img src='images/i_242.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 242</span>, <i>A-D.</i>—The nervous systems of 4 genera of Diptera, to demonstrate their various degrees of fusion of ganglia: <i>A</i>, non-concentrated more primitive nervous system of <i>Chironomus plumosus</i>, with 3 thoracic and 6 abdominal ganglionic masses. <i>B</i>, nervous system of <i>Empis stercorea</i>, with 2 thoracic and 5 abdominal ganglionic masses. <i>C</i>, nervous system of <i>Tabanus bovinus</i>, with 1 thoracic ganglionic mass, and the abdominal ganglia closely approximated. <i>D</i>, highly modified nervous system of <i>Sarcophaga carnaria</i>, in which all the ganglia of the ventral cord behind the subœsophageal ganglion are fused into a single ganglionic mass.—After Brandt, from Lang.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the Collembola, which are retrograde Thysanura, there are from
one (Smynthurus), to three or four ventral ganglia.</p>

<p class='c007'>In the winged insects, where the ganglia are more or less fused,
the fusion taking place in the head and at the end of the abdomen;
there are in the more simple and generalized forms, such as Ephemera,
the grasshopper, locusts (Fig. 240), etc., thirteen ganglia besides the
two pairs of compound ganglia in the head, three pairs of thoracic
<span class='pageno' id='Page_225'>225</span>ganglia, and usually from five to eight pairs of ganglia in the
abdomen.</p>

<div  class='figleft id042'>
<img src='images/i_243a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 243.</span>—Nervous system of the May beetle, <i>Lachnosterna fusca</i>: <i>w<sup>1</sup></i>, nerve to 1st,—<i>w<sup>2</sup></i>, nerve to 2d, pair of wings; <i>ig</i>, infraœsophageal ganglion.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id042'>
<img src='images/i_243b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 244.</span>—The same of the stag-beetle, <i>Lucanus dama</i>, where there are 3 thoracic, and 3 separate abdominal ganglia.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In certain winged insects the process of fusion or degeneration
is carried to such an extreme that there are either no abdominal
ganglia (Fig. 242, <i>D</i>), or their vestiges are situated in the thorax
and partially fused with the thoracic ones, as in the May beetle, in
which the prothoracic pair of ganglia is separate, while the two
other thoracic ganglia are fused with the abdominal, the latter being
situated in the thorax; this fusion is carried to a further extent
than in any other Coleoptera yet examined. In many Diptera and
Hemiptera the abdominal ganglia are either absent or the vestiges
are fused with the thoracic ganglia.</p>

<p class='c007'>Rhizotrogus, which is allied to our May beetle, as also Hydrometra
and the Stylopidæ are said to lack the subœsophageal ganglion
(Brandt).</p>

<p class='c007'>In numerous Coleoptera (Acilius, Gyrinus, Necrophorus, Melolontha,
Bostrichus, Rhynchænus); in many Diptera (Culex, Tipula,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_226'>226</span>Asilus, Xylophaga, and Phora); and in the higher Hymenoptera
(Crabronidæ, Vespidæ, and Apidæ), as well as in many Lepidoptera
(Vanessa, Argynnis, and Pontia), two of the thoracic ganglia are
fused together, while all three are partially fused into a single mass
in many brachycerous Diptera (Conops, Syrphus, Pangonia, and the
Muscidæ); in certain Hemiptera (Pentatoma, Nepa, and Acanthia);
also in a beetle (<i>Serica brunnea</i>). Sometimes the subœsophageal
ganglion is fused with the first thoracic, as in Acanthia, Nepa, and
Notonecta. The greatest amount of variation is seen in the number
of abdominal ganglia, all being fused into a single one or from one
to eight. The fusion is usually greatest where the abdomen is shortened,
due to the partial atrophy and modification of the terminal
segments which bear the ovipositor, where present, and the genital
armature.</p>

<p class='c007'>There is only one pair of abdominal ganglia in Gyrinus and in certain
flies (Conops, Trypeta, Ortalis, and Phora); two in Rhynchænus,
a weevil, and in the flies, Syrphus and Volucella; three in Crabro
and Eucera; four in Sargus, Stratiomys and in butterflies, five in
the beetle, Silpha, and in the fly, Sciara, and the moth, Hepialus.</p>

<p class='c007'>The nervous system in the larvæ of the metabolous orders is not
concentrated, though in that of the neuropterous Myrmeleo it has
undergone fusion from adaptation to the short compressed form of
this insect.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>b.</i> The brain</h4>

<p class='c016'>The brain of insects appears to be nearly, if not quite, as complex
as that of the lower vertebrates. As in the latter, the pair of supraœsophageal
ganglia, or brain, is the principal seat of the senses, the
chief organ of the insect’s mind.</p>

<p class='c007'>It is composed of a larger number of pairs of primitive ganglia
than any of the succeeding nerve-centres, and is, structurally, entirely
different from and far more complicated than the other ganglia of
the nervous system. It possesses a central body in each hemisphere,
a “mushroom body,” optic lobes and optic ganglia and olfactory lobe,
with their connecting and commissural nerve-fibres, and a number
of other parts not found in the other ganglia.</p>

<p class='c007'>In the succeeding ganglia the lobes are in general motor; the
fibres composing the œsophageal commissures, and which arise from
the œsophageal commissural lobes, extend not only to the subœsophageal
ganglion, but pass along through the succeeding ganglia
to the last pair of abdominal nerve-centres.<a id='r40' /><a href='#f40' class='c012'><sup>[40]</sup></a> Since, then, there is a
<span class='pageno' id='Page_227'>227</span>direct continuity in the fibres forming the two main longitudinal
commissures of the nervous cord, and which originate in the brain,
it seems to follow that the movements of the body are in large part
directed or coördinated by the brain.<a id='r41' /><a href='#f41' class='c012'><sup>[41]</sup></a> Still, however, a second
brain, so to speak, is found in the third thoracic ganglion of the
locust, which receives the auditory nerves from the ears situated in
the base of the abdomen; or in the first thoracic ganglion of the
green grasshoppers (katydids, etc.), whose ears are situated in their
fore legs; while even the last pair of abdominal ganglia in the cockroach
and mole cricket, is, so to speak, a secondary brain, since it
distributes sensory nerves to the caudal stylets, which are provided
with organs probably olfactory in nature.</p>

<p class='c007'>It is impossible to understand the morphology of the brain unless
we examine the mode of origin of the nervous system in the early
life of the embryo. The head of an embryo insect consists of six
segments, <i>i.e.</i> the ocular, antennal, premandibular, mandibular, and
the 1st and 2d maxillary segments, so named from the appendages
they bear. Of these the first three in the larva and adult are
preoral, and the last three are postoral. The antennal segment
was probably either postoral in the progenitors of insects, or the
antennæ were inserted on the side of the mouth, the latter finally
moving back.<a id='r42' /><a href='#f42' class='c012'><sup>[42]</sup></a></p>

<p class='c007'>The nervous system in the early embryonic condition, as shown
by Wheeler (Fig. 245), at first consists of nineteen pairs of primitive
ganglia, called <i>neuromeres</i>. Those of the head, which later in embryonic
life fuse together to form the brain, are the first three,
corresponding to the <i>protocerebrum</i>, <i>deutocerebrum</i>, and <i>tritocerebrum</i>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_228'>228</span>of Viallanes. The first pair of primitive ganglia, and which is
situated in front of the mouth, is divided into three lobes.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id054'>
<img src='images/i_246.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 245</span>, <i>A-D</i>.—Diagrams of four consecutive stages in the development of the brain and nerve-chain of the embryo of Xiphidium: I, cephalic,—II, thoracic,—III, abdominal, region; <i>st</i>, stomodæum or primitive mouth; <i>an</i>, anus; <i>e</i>, optic plate; <i>pc(og)</i>, 1st protocerebral lobe, or optic ganglion; <i>pc<sup>2</sup></i>, <i>pc<sup>3</sup></i>, 2d and 3d protocerebral lobes; <i>dc</i>, deutocerebrum; <i>tc</i>, tritocerebrum; 1–16, the 16 postoral ganglia; <i>po. c</i>, postoral commissure; <i>fp</i>, furcal pit; <i>ac</i>, anterior,—<i>pc</i>, posterior, ganglionic commissure; <i>ag</i>, anterior,—<i>pg</i>, posterior,—<i>cg</i>, central,—<i>lg</i>, lateral gangliomeres.—After Wheeler.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The first or outermost lobe, according to Wheeler, forms the optic
ganglion of the larva and imago, while the second and third lobes.
(<i>pc<sup>2</sup></i>, <i>pc<sup>3</sup></i>) ultimately form the bulk of the brain proper, or the protocerebral
lobes. The second (primitively postoral) brain-segment
or pair of ganglia gives origin to the antennæ, while the third brain,
or premandibular (intercalary) segment, gives origin to a temporary
embryonic pair of appendages found in Anurida and Campodea (the
premandibular ganglia), and also to the nerves supplying the labrum.
These three pairs of ganglia later on in embryonic life become
preoral, the mouth moving backwards. The three pairs of primitive
ganglia, behind, <i>i.e.</i> the mandibular and 1st and 2d maxillary ganglia,
become fused together to form the subœsophageal ganglion,
and which in larval and adult life is postoral.</p>

<p class='c007'><span class='pageno' id='Page_229'>229</span>If the tongue (ligula, or hypopharynx) represents a distinct pair
of appendages, then there are seven segments in the head.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id078'>
<img src='images/i_247a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 246.</span>—Section through head of a carabid, <i>Anopthalmus telkampfii</i>: <i>br</i>, brain; <i>fg</i>, frontal ganglion; <i>soe</i>, subœsophageal ganglion; <i>co</i>, commissure; <i>n</i>. <i>l</i>, nerve sending branches to the lingua (<i>l</i>); <i>mn</i>, maxillary nerve; <i>mx</i>, 1st maxilla; <i>mm</i>, maxillary muscle; <i>mx′</i> 2d maxilla; <i>mt</i>, muscle of mentum; <i>le</i>, elevator muscle of the œsophagus; <i>l′</i> of the clypeus, and a third beyond raising the labrum (<i>lbr</i>); <i>eph</i>, epipharynx; <i>g. g′</i>, salivary glands above; <i>g<sup>2</sup></i>, lingual gland below the œsophagus (<i>œ</i>); <i>m</i>, mouth; <i>pv</i>, proventriculus; <i>md</i>, mandible.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The brain, then, supplies nerves to the compound and simple
eyes, and to the antennæ, and gives origin to the sympathetic
nerves; it is thus the seat of the senses, also of the insect’s mind,
and coördinates the general movements of the body.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id073'>
<img src='images/i_247b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 247.</span>—Median longitudinal section through the head of <i>Blatta orientalis</i>. The nervous system of the head is drawn entire. <i>hyp</i>, hypopharynx; <i>os</i>. oral cavity; <i>lbr</i>, upper lip; <i>gf</i>, frontal ganglion; <i>g</i>, brain; <i>na</i>, root of the antennal nerve; <i>no</i>, root of the optic nerve; <i>ga</i>, anterior,—<i>gp</i>, posterior ganglion of the paired visceral nervous system; <i>œ</i>, œsophagus; <i>c</i>, œsophageal commissure; <i>usg</i>, infraœsophageal ganglia; <i>cc</i>, longitudinal commissure between this and the first thoracic ganglion; <i>sg</i>, common duct of the salivary glands; <i>lb</i>, labium (2d maxillæ); <i>nr</i>, recurrent nerve; <i>d</i>, nerve uniting the frontal ganglion with the œsophageal commissure; <i>e</i>, nerve from this commissure to the labrum; <i>f</i>, nerve from the infraœsophageal ganglion to the mandible, —<i>g</i>, to the 1st maxillæ, —<i>h</i>, to the lower lip (2d maxillæ).—After Hofer,
from Lang.</p>
</div>
</div>
<div  class='figcenter id079'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_231'>231</span>
<img src='images/i_248.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 248.</span>—1, front view of the brain of <i>Melanoplus femur-rubrum</i>: <i>opt. gang</i>, optic ganglion; <i>oc</i>, ocelli and nerves leading to them from the two hemispheres, each ocellar nerve arising from the region containing the calices; <i>m. oc</i>, median ocellar nerve; <i>opt. l</i>, optic lobe sending off the optic nerve to the optic ganglion; <i>ant. l</i>, antennal or olfactory lobe; <i>ant. n</i>, antennal nerve; <i>f. g</i>, frontal ganglion of sympathetic nerve; <i>lbr. n</i>, nerve to labrum; <i>x</i>, cross-nerve or commissure between the two hemispheres; <i>œ. c</i>, œsophageal commissure to subœsophageal ganglion. 2, side view of the brain and subœsophageal ganglion (lettering of brain as in 1): <i>s. g</i>, stomatogastric or sympathetic nerve; <i>a. s. g</i>, anterior, and <i>p. s. g</i>, posterior, sympathetic ganglia; <i>g<sup>2</sup></i>, subœsophageal ganglion; <i>md</i>, nerve to mandible; <i>mx</i>, maxillary nerve; <i>ln</i>, labial
nerve; <i>nl</i>, unknown nerve,—perhaps salivary. 3, interior view of the right half of the head, showing the brain in its natural position: <i>an</i>, antenna; <i>cl</i>, clypeus; <i>lbr</i>, labrum; <i>m</i>, mouth-cavity; <i>md</i>, mandible; <i>t</i>, tongue; <i>œ</i>, œsophagus; <i>c</i>, crop; <i>en</i>, right half of the endocranium or <b><span class='mono'>X</span></b>-shaped bone, through the anterior angle of which the œsophagus passes, while the great mandibular muscles play in the lateral angles. The moon-shaped edge is that made by the knife passing through the centre of the <b><span class='mono'>X</span></b>. 4, view of brain from above (letters as before). 5, subœsophageal ganglion from above: <i>t. c</i>, commissure to the succeeding thoracic ganglion (other letters as before). Fig. 3 is enlarged 8 times; all the rest 25 times.—Drawn from original dissections, by Mr. Edward Burgess, for the Second Report of the U. S. Entomological Commission.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The pair of subœsophageal ganglia distributes nerves to the
mandibles, to the 1st and 2d maxillæ, and to the salivary glands
(Fig. 248).</p>

<p class='c007'>Its general shape and relations to the walls and to the outer
organs of the head is seen in Figs. 247, 248. In all the winged
insects (Pterygota) its plane is situated more or less at right angles
to the horizontal plane of the ventral cord. On the dorsal and
anterior sides are situated the ocular lobes, and below these the
antennal lobes.</p>

<p class='c007'>Viallanes first, independently of embryonic data, divided the
brain of adult insects into three regions or segments; <i>i.e.</i> the “<i>protocerebron</i>,”
“<i>deutocerebron</i>” and “<i>tritocerebron</i>,” which he afterwards
found to correspond with the three primitive elements
(neuromeres) of the brain and with the segments of the head of the
embryo.</p>

<p class='c007'>The brain of the locusts (Melanoplus and Œdipoda) being best
known will serve as the basis of the following description, taken
mainly from Viallanes, with minor changes in the name of the three
segments, and other modifications.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>I.</b> <b>The optic or procerebral segment</b> is composed of a median portion,
<i>i.e.</i> two fused procerebral lobes (median protocerebrum), and
of two lateral masses, the optic ganglia (<i>protocerebrum</i>), and comprises
the following regions fused together and forming the median
procerebral mass (Viallanes):—</p>

<div class='lg-container-b c025'>
  <div class='linegroup'>
    <div class='group'>
      <div class='line'>1. Procerebral lobes.</div>
      <div class='line'>2. Optic ganglia.</div>
      <div class='line'>3. Layer of postretinal fibres.</div>
      <div class='line'>4. Ganglionic plate. (<i>Periopticon</i> of Hickson.)</div>
      <div class='line'>5. External chiasma.</div>
      <div class='line'>6. External medullary mass. (<i>Epiopticon</i> of Hickson.)</div>
      <div class='line'>7. Internal chiasma.</div>
      <div class='line'><span class='pageno' id='Page_232'>232</span>8. Internal medullary mass. (<i>Opticon</i> of Hickson.)</div>
      <div class='line'>9. Optic ganglia and nerves.</div>
      <div class='line'>10. Pedunculated or stalked body. (Mushroom body of Dujardin.)</div>
      <div class='line'>11. Bridge of the procerebral lobes.</div>
      <div class='line'>12. Central body.</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

<div  class='figcenter id080'>
<img src='images/i_250.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 249.</span>—Diagram of an insect’s brain: <i>cc</i>, central body; <i>cg</i>, ganglionic cells; <i>che</i>, external, <i>chi</i>, internal chiasma; <i>cœ</i>, œsophageal commissure; <i>cp</i>, mushroom body; <i>ctc</i>, tritocerebral commissure; <i>fpr</i>, postretinal fibres; <i>goc</i>, ocellar ganglion; <i>goc</i><sup>1</sup>, œsophageal ganglion, the dotted ring the œsophagus; <i>gv<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>gc<sup>2</sup></i>, <i>gv<sup>3</sup></i>, 1st, 2d, 3d, unpaired visceral ganglion; <i>gvl</i>, lateral visceral ganglion; <i>ld</i>, dorsal lobe of the deutocerebrum; <i>lg</i>, ganglionic plate; <i>lo</i>, olfactory lobe; <i>lpc</i>, protocerebral lobe; <i>me</i>, external, <i>mi</i>, internal medullary mass; <i>na</i>, olfactory or antennal nerve; <i>nl</i>, nerve to labrum; <i>no</i>, ocular nerve; <i>nt</i>, tegumentary nerve; <i>œ</i>, œsophagus; <i>plp</i>, bridge of the protocerebral lobes; <i>rvd</i>, visceral root arising from the deutocerebrum; <i>rvt</i>,
visceral root arising from the tritocerebrum; <i>tr</i>, tritocerebrum; <i>to</i>, optic nerve or tract.—After Viallanes.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>Optic ganglia.</b>—Each of the two optic ganglia is formed of a
series of three ganglionic masses situated between the compound
eyes and the median procerebral mass, <i>i.e.</i> the ganglionic plate
(Fig. 249, <i>lg</i>), the external medullary mass (<i>me</i>), and the internal
medullary mass (<i>mi</i>).</p>

<p class='c007'>The postretinal fibres (<i>fpr</i>) arising from the facets or single eyes of
the compound eye (ommatidia) pass into the ganglionic plate (<i>lg</i>),
which is united within by the chiasmatic fibres (<i>che</i>, external chiasma)
of the external medullary mass (<i>me</i>). The last is attached to the
internal medullary mass (<i>mi</i>) by fibres (<i>chi</i>), some of which are chiasmatic,
and others direct. Finally, the internal medullary mass connects
with the median part of the protocerebrum by direct fibres
forming the optic nerve or tract (<i>to</i>).</p>

<p class='c007'><b>Procerebral lobes.</b>—The median procerebral lobes are fused together
on the median line, forming a single central mass. From each side
<span class='pageno' id='Page_233'>233</span>or lobe arises the mushroom or stalked body. In the middle of the
mass is the central body, and directly in front is the procerebral
bridge (<i>plp</i>). The latter is a band uniting the two halves of the
brain.</p>

<p class='c007'>The procerebral lobes also give origin to the nerves to the
ocelli (<i>no</i>).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id048'>
<img src='images/i_251.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 250.</span>—Transverse section through the brain of the locust (Œdipoda and Caloptenus): <i>c′</i>, lower part of the wall of <i>c</i>, calyx;—<i>st</i>, stalk of the same; <i>bpcl</i>, bridge of the protocerebral lobes; <i>mo</i>, nerve of median ocellus; <i>ch</i>, transverse fascia of the optico-olfactory chiasma; <i>fcb</i>, fibrous region of the central body; <i>lcb</i>, tubercle of the central body; <i>fch</i>, descending fascia of the optico-olfactory chiasma; <i>choo</i>, superior fascia of the optico-olfactory chiasma; <i>pt</i>, protocerebral lobes; <i>ld</i>, dorsal lobe of the deutocerebrum; <i>lt</i>, tritocerebral lobe; <i>gcld</i>, <i>gc</i>, ganglion cells.—After Viallanes.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>The mushroom or stalked bodies.</b>—These remarkable organs were
first discovered by Dujardin, who compared them to mushrooms, and
observed that they were more highly developed in ants, wasps, and
bees than in the lower insects, and thus inferred that the higher
intelligence of these insects was in direct relation to the development
of these bodies. We will call them the <i>mushroom bodies</i>.</p>

<p class='c007'>These two bodies consist of a rounded lobular mass (the trabecula)
of the procerebral lobe, from which arises a double stalk (Fig. 253),
the larger called the <i>cauliculus</i>, the smaller the <i>peduncle</i> (or pedicel);
these support the cap or <i>calyx</i>. The calices of the bee were compared
by Dujardin to a pair of disks on each side of the brain as
seen from above, “each disk being folded together and bent downwards
before and behind, its border being thickened, and the inner
<span class='pageno' id='Page_234'>234</span>portion radiated.” In the locust there are but two divisions of the
calyx; in the cockroach, ants, wasps, and bees, four.</p>

<p class='c007'>The shape and relation of the mushroom bodies are represented
in Figs. 252 and 253. The bodies are connected by commissural
fibres, and are connected with the optic ganglion of the same side,
and with the central body; while they are connected with the
antennal lobes by the optico-olfactory chiasma.</p>

<div  class='figleft id019'>
<img src='images/i_252.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 251.</span>—Sagittal section through the brain of the locust: <i>l. oc. n</i>, lateral ocellus nerve; <i>a. t</i>, anterior tubercle of the mushroom body; <i>i. t</i>, internal tubercle of the mushroom body; <i>c. l</i>, cerebral lobes; <i>l. l</i>, lateral lobe of the middle protocerebrum; <i>com</i>, commissural cord; <i>c. mol</i>, central mass of the olfactory lobe; <i>ac. an. l</i>, fibres uniting the median lobe of the middle protocerebrum with dorsal lobes of the deutocerebrum; <i>gc. trit. l</i>, ganglionated cortex of the tritocerebral lobe; <i>c. an. l</i>, cortex of antennal (olfactory) lobe; <i>lab. fr</i>, labrofrontal nerve; <i>oe. com</i>, œsophageal commissure; <i>tr. com</i>, transverse commissure of œsophageal ring; other letters as in Fig. 250.—After Viallanes.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The stalked bodies are
enveloped by the cortical
layers of ganglion-cells, those
filling the hollow of the calyx
having little or no protoplasm
around the nucleus.</p>

<p class='c013'><b>Structure of the mushroom
bodies.</b>—By staining the brain
of the honey bee with bichromate
of silver, Kenyon has worked out
the structure of the mushroom
bodies, with their cells. The cup-shaped
bodies or calyces are
composed of fibrillar substance
(<i>punktsubstanz</i>). Each of these
cups, he says, is “filled to overflowing
with cells having large
nuclei and very little cytoplasm.”
From the under surface of each
of these cups there descends into
the general fibrillar substance of
the brain “a column of fibrillar
substance, which unites with its
fellow of the same side to send a
large branch obliquely downward
to the median line of the brain,
and an equally large or larger
branch straight forwards to the
anterior cerebral surface.”</p>

<p class='c013'>The cells of the mushroom
bodies, observes Kenyon, “stand
out in sharp contrast to all other
nerve cells known, though they
recall to some extent the cells of
Purkinje in the higher mammals.
Each of the cells contained within the fibrillar cup sends a nerve-process into the
latter, where it breaks up into a profusely arborescent system of branchlets,
which often appear with fine, short, lateral processes, such as are characteristic
of the dendrites of some mammalian nerve-cells.” Just before entering the
fibrillar substance, a fine branch is given off that travels along the inner surface
of the cup along with others of the same nature, forming a small bundle to the
stalk of the mushroom body, down which it continues until it reaches the origin
<span class='pageno' id='Page_235'>235</span>of the anterior and the inner roots above mentioned. “Here it branches, one
branch continuing straight on to the end of the anterior root, while the other
passes to the end of the inner root. Throughout its whole course the fibre and
its two branches are very fine. Nearly the whole stalk and nearly the whole
of each root is made up of these straight, parallel fibres coming from the cells
within the cup of the mushroom bodies. What other fibres there are enter
these bodies from the side, and branch between the straight fibres very much as
the dendrites of the cells of Purkinje branch among the parallel fine fibres from
the cells of the granular layer in the mammalian cerebellum. These fibres are
of the nature of association fibres.”</p>

<p class='c013'>Viallanes showed that from the olfactory or antennal lobes, as well as from
the optic ganglia, there are tracts of fibres which finally enter the cups of the
mushroom bodies, and Kenyon has confirmed this observation. Kenyon has
also, by the Golgi method, detected another tract, before unknown, “passing
down the hinder side of the brain, from the cups to the region above the œsophagus,
where it bends forward and comes in contact with fibres from the ventral
cord, which exists, although Binet was unable to discover any growth of fibres
connecting the cord with the brain.</p>

<p class='c013'>“The fibres entering the cups from the antennal lobe, the optic ganglia, and
the ventral region, spread out and branch among the arborescent endings of
the mushroom-body cells. The fibres branching among the parallel fibres of
the roots and the stalk lead off to lower parts of the brain, connecting with
efferent or motor-fibres, or with secondary association fibres, that in their turn
make such connections. This portion of the circuit has not been perfectly made
out, though there seems to be sufficient data to warrant the assumption just
made.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id048'>
<img src='images/i_253.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 252.</span>—Section 17, showing the central body (<i>centr. b</i>) and mushroom body, optic and antennal lobes (<i>a. l</i>), and procerebral lobes (<i>pc. l</i>); <i>o. cal</i>, outer division of the calyx; <i>op. n</i>, optic nerve; <i>trab</i>, trabeculum; <i>tc. n</i>, transverse nerve.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>“Such fibres existing as described, there is then a complete circuit for sensory
stimuli from the various parts of the body to the cells of the mushroom bodies.
The dendritic or arborescent branches of these cells take them up and pass them
on out along the parallel fibres or neurites in the roots of the mushroom bodies
as motor or other efferent impulses.</p>

<p class='c013'>“This, however, is not all. For there are numerous fibres evident in my
preparations, the full courses of which I have not been thus far able to determine,
but which are so situated as to warrant the inference that they may act as
<span class='pageno' id='Page_236'>236</span>association fibres between the afferent fibres from the antennæ, optic ganglia,
and ventral system, and the efferent fibres. There is then a possibility of a
stimulus entering the brain and passing out as a motor impulse without going
into the circuit of the fibres of the mushroom bodies; or, in other words, a
possibility of what may be compared to reflex action in higher animals.”</p>

<div  class='figcenter id080'>
<img src='images/i_254.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 253.</span>—Enlarged view of the trabeculum (the dotted lines <i>tcn</i> and <i>obt. n</i> pass through it) and its nerves, of the mushroom body,—its calices and stalk, and the origin of the optic nerve × 225 diameters: <i>atn</i>, ascending trabecular nerve; <i>obt. n</i>, oblique trabecular nerve; <i>tcn</i>, transverse nerve; <i>lat. n</i>, lateral nerve; <i>cent. n</i>, central nerve.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The mushroom bodies have not yet been found to be present in
the Synaptera, but occur in the larvæ, at least of those of most
metamorphic insects (Lepidoptera and Hymenoptera), though not
yet found in the larvæ of Diptera. The writer has found these bodies
in the nymphs of the locust (<i>Melanoplus spretus</i>), but not in the embryo
just before hatching. They occur in the third larval or nymph
stage of this insect. It is evident that by the end of the first larval
stage the brain attains the development seen in the third larval
state of the two-banded species (<i>C. bivittatus</i>).</p>

<div  class='figleft id010'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_237'>237</span>
<img src='images/i_255.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 254.</span>—Section through the brain of <i>Caloptenus bivittatus</i> in the third larval stage, showing the two hemispheres or sides of the brain, and the ocelli and ocellar nerves, which are seen to arise from the top of the hemispheres directly over the calices (compare Fig. 251): <i>o. cal</i>, outer division of calyx of left mushroom body.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The result of our studies on the brain of the embryo locust was
that from the embryonic cerebral lobes are eventually developed
the central body and the two mushroom bodies. Fig. 254 shows
the early condition of the
mushroom bodies and their
undoubted origin from the
cerebral ganglia. Hence these
bodies appear to be differentiations
of the cerebral
ganglia or lobes, having no
connection with the optic or
antennal lobes.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The central body</b> (Fig. 252,
<i>centr. b</i>).—This is the only
single or unpaired organ in
the brain. Dietl characterizes
it as a median commissural
system. Viallanes describes
it as formed entirely of a
very fine and close fibrillar
web, like a thick hemispherical skull-cap, situated on the median
line and united with the cerebral lobes. “It is like a central post
towards which converge fibres passing from all points of the brain;
being bound to the cerebral lobes, to the stalked bodies, to the optic
ganglia, and to the olfactory lobes by distinct fibrous bundles.”</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The antennal or olfactory lobes (Deutocerebrum).</b>—This portion of
the brain consists of two hemispherical lobes, highly differentiated
for special sensorial perceptions, and connected by a slightly differentiated
medullary mass, the dorsal lobe (Figs. 248, 249 <i>lo</i>), from
which arise the motor fibres and those of general sensibility. The
antennal lobes are in part attached to the optic ganglia, and partly
to the stalked body on the same side, by the optic olfactory chiasma
(Fig. 250 <i>fch</i>, <i>choo</i>), a system of fibres partially intercrossed on the
median line.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The œsophageal lobes (Tritocerebrum)</b> (Figs. 249, 250).—From this
region the labrum and viscera are innervated, the nerves to the latter
being called the visceral, sympathetic, or stomatogastric system. As
Viallanes remarks, though plainly situated in front of the mouth,
they are in fact post-œsophageal centres. The two lobes are situated
far apart, and are connected by a bundle of fibres passing
behind the œsophagus, called the transverse commissure of the
œsophageal ring (Lienard). The œsophageal ganglia, besides giving
<span class='pageno' id='Page_238'>238</span>rise to the labral nerves, also give origin to the root of the frontal
ganglion.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>c.</i> Histological elements of the brain</h4>

<p class='c016'>The brain and other ganglia are composed of two kinds of tissue.</p>

<p class='c007'>1. The outer slightly darker, usually pale grayish white portion
consists of cortical or ganglion-cells differing in size. This portion
is stained red by carmine, the cells composing it readily taking the
stain.</p>

<p class='c007'>The large ganglion cells (represented in Figs. 252 and 253) are
oval, and send off usually a single nerve-fibre; they have a thin fibrous
cell-wall, and the contents are finely granular. The nucleus is very
large, often one-half the diameter of the entire cell, and is composed
of large round refractive granules, usually concealing the nucleolus.</p>

<p class='c007'>2. The medullary or inner part of the brain consists of matter
which remains white or unstained after the preparation has remained
thoroughly exposed to the action of the carmine. It consists of
minute granules and interlacing fibres. The latter often forms a
fine irregular network inclosing masses of finely granulated nerve
matter.</p>

<p class='c013'>This is called by Dietl “marksubstanz.” Leydig, in his Vom Bau des thierischen
Körpers, p. 89, thus refers to it:—</p>

<p class='c013'>“In the brain and ventral ganglia of the leech, of insects, and in the brain of
the gastropods (Schnecken) I observe that the stalks (stiele) of the ganglion-cells
in nowise immediately arise as nerve-fibres, but are planted in a molecular
mass or <i>punktsubstanz</i>, situated in the centre of the ganglion, and merged with
this substance. It follows, from what I have seen, that there is no doubt that
<i>the origin of the nerve-fibres first takes place from this central punktsubstanz</i>.”</p>

<p class='c013'>“This relation is the rule. But there also occur in the nerve-centres of the
invertebrates single, definitely situated ganglion-cells, whose continuations
become nerve-fibres without the intervention of a superadded <i>punktsubstanz</i>.”
We may, with Kenyon, call it the fibrillar substance.</p>

<p class='c013'>Leydig subsequently (p. 91) further describes this fibrillar substance, stating
that the granules composing it form a reticulated mass of fibrillæ, or, in other
words, a tangled web of very fine fibres:—</p>

<p class='c013'>“We at present consider that by the passage of the continuation of the
ganglion-cells into the <i>punktsubstanz</i> this continuation becomes lost in the fine
threads, and on the other side of the <i>punktsubstanz</i> the similar fibrillar substance
forms the origin of the axis-cylinders arranged parallel to one another; so it is
quite certain <i>that the single axis-cylinder derives its fibrillar substance as a
mixture from the most diverse ganglion-cells</i>.”</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>d.</i> The visceral (sympathetic or stomatogastric) system</h4>

<p class='c016'>This system in insects is composed (1) of a series of three unpaired
ganglia (Fig. 249, <i>gv<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>gv<sup>2</sup></i>, <i>gv<sup>3</sup></i>), situated over the dorso-median line of
the œsophagus, and connected by a median nervous cord or recurrent
<span class='pageno' id='Page_239'>239</span>nerve (<i>nr</i>, <i>vagus</i> of Newport). The first of these ganglia is the
frontal ganglion, which is connected with the œsophageal ganglia by
a pair of roots (<i>rvt</i>), which have an origin primitively common with
that of the labral nerves (Fig. 248, <i>fg</i> and <i>lbr</i>).</p>

<div  class='figright id020'>
<img src='images/i_257.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 255.</span>—Anterior portion of the paired and unpaired visceral nervous system of <i>Blatta orientalis</i> seen from above. The outlines of the brain (<i>g</i>) and the roots of the antennal nerve (<i>na</i>), which cover a portion of the sympathetic nervous system, are given by dotted lines. Lettering as in Fig. 247. <i>nsd</i>, nerve to salivary gland. The nervus recurrens (<i>nr</i>) enters an unpaired stomach ganglion farther back.—After Hofer, from Lang.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>2. Of two pairs of lateral ganglia (Fig. 255, <i>ga</i>, <i>gp</i>) situated two on
each side of the œsophagus. They are connected both with the
antennal lobes by a nerve (<i>rvd</i>), and to the chain of unpaired ganglia
by a special connective. The first
pair of these ganglia sends nerves
to the heart and aorta; the second
pair to the tracheæ of the head.</p>

<p class='c007'>The unpaired median or recurrent
nerve (<i>nr</i>) extends back from
under the brain along the upper
side of the œsophagus, and (in
Blatta), behind the origin of the
nerves to the salivary glands,
enters an unpaired ganglion, called
the stomachic ganglion (<i>ganglion
ventriculare</i>), situated in front of
the proventriculus. The number
of these stomachic ganglia varies
in different orders of insects.</p>

<p class='c013'>In Blatta, Küpffer and also Hofer
have shown (Fig. 255) (Müller, Brandt,
<i>ex</i> Kolbe) that the nerve to each salivary
gland arises from three different
centres: the anterior end situated under
the œsophagus is innervated by the
paired visceral nerves from the hinder
paired ganglia; the remaining part by
nerves arising from each side of the
recurrent nerve; and thirdly by a pair
of nerves arising from the subœsophageal
ganglion which accompanies the common
salivary duct, and ends in branches which partly innervate the salivary
glands and in part their muscles.</p>

<p class='c007'>Hofer considers that the function of this complex system of paired
and unpaired ganglia, with their nerves, is a double one, viz. serving
both as a centre for the peristaltic action of the œsophagus, and as
innervating the salivary glands.</p>

<p class='c007'>Besides these a second portion of the visceral system arises from
the thoracic and abdominal ventral cord. It may be seen in the
<span class='pageno' id='Page_240'>240</span>simplest condition yet known in the nervous system of Machilis
(Fig. 239 <i>s</i>). It consists of a fine, slender nerve, which extends
along the surface of the ventral chain of ganglia, and sending off a
pair of branches (accessory transverse nerves) in front of each
ganglion. These accessory nerves receive nerve-twigs from the
upper cord of the ventral chain, dilating near their origins into a
minute elongated ganglion, and then passing partly outwards to the
branches of the tracheæ and the muscles of the spiracles, uniting in
the middle line of each segment of the body behind the head, <i>i.e.</i> of
those segments containing a pair of ganglia.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>e.</i> The supraspinal cord</h4>

<p class='c016'>In the adult Lepidoptera has been detected, continuous with and
on the upper side of the abdominal portions of the ventral cord, a
longitudinal cord of connective tissue forming a white or yellowish
band, and which seems to be an outgrowth of the dorsal portion of
the neurilemma of the ventral cord. Muscles pass from it to the
neighboring ventral portions of the integument. Its use is unknown,
and attention was first called to it by Treviranus, who called it “an
unknown ventral vessel” (<i>Bauchgefäss</i>). Afterwards it was re-discovered
by Newport, who described it as “a distinct vascular canal.”
But Burger has proved by cross-sections that it is not tubular, but
a comparatively solid cord composed, however, of loose connective
tissue. Newport found it in the larva of <i>Sphinx ligustri</i>, but Cattie
states that it is not present in that of <i>Acherontia atropos</i>. It has
not yet been observed in insects of other orders, but its homologue
exists in the scorpion and in the centipede, and it may prove to
correspond with the far more complete arterial coat which, with the
exception of the brain, envelops the nervous system of Limulus.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>f.</i> Modifications of the brain in different orders of insects</h4>

<p class='c016'>There are different grades of cerebral development in insects, and
Viallanes claimed that it was no exaggeration to say that the brain
of the locust (Melanoplus) differs as much from that of the wasp
as that of the frog differs from that of man. He insists that the
physiological conditions which determine the anatomical modifications
of the brain are correlated with 1, the food; 2, the perfection
of the senses; and 3, with the perfection of the psychic
faculties. For example, in those which feed on solid food and
whose œsophagus is large (Orthoptera and Coleoptera), the connectives
are elongated, the subœsophageal commissure free in all
<span class='pageno' id='Page_241'>241</span>its extent, and the tritocerebrum is situated quite far from the preceding
segment of the brain.</p>

<p class='c007'>On the other hand, in insects which feed on fluid food (Hymenoptera,
Lepidoptera, Diptera, Hemiptera), the œsophagus is slender
and the nervous centres which surround them are very much condensed;
the connectives are short, and the tritocerebrum is closely
fused, partly to a portion of the antennal lobes (deutocerebrum)
and partly to the mandibular ganglion.</p>

<p class='c007'>As regards the perfection of the senses, where, as in dragon-flies,
the eyes are very large, the optic ganglia are correspondingly so,
and in the same insects the antennæ being very small, the antennal
lobes are almost rudimentary. The ants exhibit inverse conditions;
in their brain the antennal lobes are well developed, while the optic
ganglia are reduced, and where, as in Typhlopone, the eyes are
wanting, they are completely atrophied.</p>

<div  class='figleft id030'>
<img src='images/i_259a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 256.</span>—Head of <i>Anophthalmus tellkampfii</i>, showing the brain,—the optic ganglia, nerves, and eyes totally atrophied.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id042'>
<img src='images/i_259b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 257.</span>—Head of another Carabid, with the brain and eyes normal: <i>op</i>, optic ganglion; <i>pcl</i>, brain.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In certain cave insects where the eyes are wanting, the optic
ganglia are also absent. In the eyeless cave species of Anophthalmus
the optic ganglia and nerves are entirely atrophied, as they are
in Adelops, which, however, has vestiges of the facets (ommatidia).
Fig. 257 represents the brain of <i>Chlænius pennsylvanicus</i>, a Carabid
beetle, with its eyes and optic ganglia (<i>op</i>) which may be compared
with Anopthalmus, in which these parts are totally atrophied.</p>

<p class='c007'>Dujardin claimed that the degree of complication of the stalked
body of the Hymenoptera was in direct relation with their mental
powers. This has been proved by Forel, who has shown that in the
honey bee and ants the mushroom bodies are much more developed
in the workers than in the males or females and Viallanes adds
that these bodies are almost rudimentary in the dragon-flies, whose
eyes are so large; while on the contrary in the blind ants (Typhlopone),
these bodies are as perfect and voluminous as in the ants
with eyes.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id044'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_242'>242</span>
<img src='images/i_260.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 258.</span>—Diagrammatic outlines of sections of the upper part of the brain of a cockroach. Only one side of the brain is here represented. The numbers indicate the position in the series of 34 sections into which this brain was cut. <i>mb</i>, mushroom bodies, with their cellular covering (<i>c</i>) and their stems (<i>st</i>); <i>a</i>, anterior nervous mass; <i>m</i>, median nervous mass.—After Newton.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><span class='pageno' id='Page_243'>243</span>Within the limits of the same order the stalked bodies are most
perfect in the most intelligent forms. Thus in the Orthoptera, says
Viallanes, the Blattæ, Forficulæ, and the crickets, the mushroom
bodies are more perfect than in the locusts, which have simpler
herbivorous habits. This perfection of the mushroom bodies is seen
not only in the increase in size, but also in the complication of its
structures. Thus in the groups with lower instincts (Tabanus,
Æschna) the stalk does not end in a calyx projecting from the
surface of the brain, but its end, simply truncated, is indicated
externally only by an accumulation of the ganglionic nuclei which
cover it.<a id='r43' /><a href='#f43' class='c012'><sup>[43]</sup></a></p>

<p class='c007'>In types which Viallanes regards as more advanced, <i>i.e.</i> Œdipoda
and Melanoplus, the end of the stalk projects and is folded into a
calyx.</p>

<p class='c007'>The brain of the cockroach (Periplaneta, Fig. 258) is a step higher
than that of the locusts, each calyx being divided into two adjacent
calices, although the cockroaches are an older and more generalized
type than locusts.</p>

<p class='c007'>The stalked bodies of cockroaches are thus complex, like those
of the higher Hymenoptera, the calices in Xylocopa, Bombus, and
Apis being double and so large as to cover almost the entire surface
of the brain.</p>

<p class='c007'>Finally, in what Viallanes regards as the most perfect type (Vespa),
the sides of the calices are folded and become sinuous, so as to increase
the surface, thus assuming an appearance which, he claims, strongly
recalls that of the convolutions of the brain of the mammals.</p>

<p class='c013'>Cheshire also calls attention to a progression in the size of these appendages,
as well as in mental powers as we rise from the cockchafer (<i>Melolontha vulgaris</i>)
to the cricket, up to the ichneumon, then to the carpenter bee, and finally
to the social hive bee, “where the pedunculated bodies form the ⅕ part of the
volume of the cerebral mass, and the <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>870</span></span> of the volume of the entire creature,
while in the cockchafer they are less than <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>2300</span></span> the part. The size of the brain
is also a gauge of intelligence. In the worker bee the brain is <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>174</span></span> of the body;
in the red ant, <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>296</span></span>; in the Melolontha, <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>3500</span></span>; in the Dyticus beetle, <span class='fraction'>1<br /><span class='vincula'>4400</span></span>.”
(Bees and bee-keeping, p. 54.)</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>g.</i> Functions of the nerve-centres and nerves</h4>

<p class='c016'>As we have seen, the central seat of the functions of the nervous
system is not the brain alone (supraœsophageal ganglion), but each
ganglion is more or less the seat of vital movements, those of the
<span class='pageno' id='Page_244'>244</span>abdomen being each a distinct motor and respiratory centre. The
two halves of a ganglion are independent of each other.</p>

<p class='c007'>According to Faivre, the brain is the seat of the will and of the
power of coördinating the movements of the body, while the
infraœsophageal ganglion is the seat of the motive power and also
of the will.</p>

<p class='c007'>The physiological experiments of Binet, which are in the line of
those of Faivre, but more thorough, demonstrate that an insect may
live for months without a brain, if the subœsophageal ganglion is
left intact, just as a vertebrate may exist without its cerebrum. As
Kenyon says: “Faivre long ago showed that the subœsophageal
ganglion is the seat of the power of coördination of the muscular
movements of the body. Binet has shown that the brain is the
seat of the power directing these movements. ‘A debrained hexapod
will eat when food is placed beneath its palpi, but it cannot go
to its food even though the latter be but a very small space removed
from its course or position. Whether the insect would be able to
do so if the mushroom bodies only were destroyed, and the antennal
lobes, optic lobes, and the rest of the brain were left intact, is a
question that yet remains to be answered’” (Kenyon).</p>

<p class='c007'>In insects which are beheaded, however readily they respond to
stimulation of the nerves, they are almost completely wanting in
will power. Yet insects which have been decapitated can still walk
and fly. Hymenoptera will live one or two days after decapitation,
beetles from one to three days, and moths (Agrotis) will show signs
of life five days after the loss of their head.</p>

<p class='c007'>That the loss of will power is gradual was proved by decapitating
<i>Polistes pallipes</i>. A day after the operation she was standing on her
legs and opening and closing her wings; 41 hours after the operation
she was still alive, moving her legs, and thrusting out her sting when
irritated. <i>Ichneumon otiosus</i>, after the removal of its head, remained
very lively, and cleaned its wings and legs, the power of coördination
in its wings and legs remaining. A horse-fly, a day after decapitation,
was lively and flew about in a natural manner.<a id='r44' /><a href='#f44' class='c012'><sup>[44]</sup></a></p>

<p class='c007'>When the abdomen is cut off, respiration in that region is not at
first interrupted. The seat of respiratory movements was referred
by Faivre to the hinder thoracic ganglion, but Plateau says that this
view must be entirely abandoned, remarking: “All carefully performed
experiments on the nervous system of Arthropoda have
shown that each ganglion of the ventral chain is a motor centre, and
<span class='pageno' id='Page_245'>245</span>in insects a respiratory centre, for the somite to which it belongs”
(Miall and Denny’s The Cockroach, p. 164).</p>

<p class='c007'>The last pair of abdominal ganglia serve as the nervous centre
of the nerves sent to the genital organs.</p>

<p class='c007'>The recurrent or stomatogastric nerve, which, through the medium
of the frontal ganglion, regulates digestion, has only a slight degree
of sensibility; the insect remains quiet even when a powerful allurement
is presented to the digestive tract (Kolbe).</p>

<p class='c007'>Faivre states that the destruction of the frontal ganglion, or a
section of the commissures connecting it with the brain, puts an end
to swallowing movements; on the other hand, stimulation results
in energetic movements of this nature.</p>

<p class='c007'>Yersin, by cutting through the commissure in different places, and
thus isolating the ganglia of the nervous cord of <i>Gryllus campestris</i>,
arrived at the following results:—</p>

<p class='c007'>1. The section of a nerve near its origin rendered the organ supplied
by this nerve incapable of performing its functions.</p>

<p class='c007'>2. If the connectives between two ganglia, <i>i.e.</i> the second and third
thoracic ganglia, are cut through, the fore as well as hinder parts of
the body retain their power of motion and sensation; but a stimulus
applied to the anterior part of the body does not pass to the hinder
portion.</p>

<p class='c007'>3. Insects with an incomplete metamorphosis after section of the
connectives are not in every case unable to moult and to farther
develop.</p>

<p class='c007'>4. If only one of the two connectives be cut through, the appendages
of the side cut through which take their origin between the
place injured and the hinder end of the body, often lose sensation
and freedom of motion, or the power of coördination of movements
becomes irregular. Sometimes this is shown by an unsteadiness in
the gait, so that the insect walks around in a circle; after a while
these irregularities cease, and the movements of the limbs on the
injured side are only slightly restrained. By a section of both connectives
in any one place the power of coördination of movements is
not injured.</p>

<p class='c007'>5. The section of the connectives appear to have no influence on
nutrition, but affects reproduction, the attempt at fertilization on the
part of the male producing no result, and the impregnated female
laying no eggs.</p>

<p class='c007'>6. Injury to the brain, or to the subœsophageal, or one of the
thoracic ganglia, is followed by a momentary enfeeblement of the
ganglion affected. Afterwards there results a convulsive trembling,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_246'>246</span>which either pervades the whole body or only the appendages
innervated by the injured ganglion.</p>

<p class='c007'>7. As a result of an injury to the brain there is such a lack of
steadiness in the movements that the insect walks or flies in a circle;
for instance, a fly or dragon-fly thus injured in flying describes a
circle or spiral. Steiner, in making this experiment, observed that
the insect circled on its uninjured side. The brain is thus a motor
centre.</p>

<p class='c007'>8. By injuring a thoracic ganglion, one or all the organs which
receive nerves from the ganglion are momentarily weakened. Afterwards
the functions become restored. Sometimes, however, the
insect walks in a circle. Faivre observed that after the destruction
of the metathoracic ganglion of <i>Dyticus marginalis</i> the hind wings
and hind legs were partially paralyzed (Kolbe, <i>ex</i> Yersin).</p>

<h3 class='c002'>LITERATURE ON THE NERVOUS SYSTEM</h3>
<h4 class='c011'><i>a.</i> General</h4>

<p class='c017'><b>Newport, George.</b> On the nervous system of the <i>Sphinx ligustri</i> L., and on the
changes which it undergoes during a part of the metamorphoses of the insect.
(Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., London, 1832, pp. 383–398; 1834, pp. 389–423, Pls.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Helmholtz, H. L. F.</b> <span lang="la" xml:lang="la">De fabrica systematis nervosi evertebratorum. Diss. in
aug. Berolini, 1842.</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Blanchard, E.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Recherches anatomiques et zoologiques sur le système nerveux des
animaux sans vertèbres. Du système nerveux des insectes. (Annales des
Sciences nat., Sér. 3, v, 1846, pp. 273–379, 8 Pls.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Du système nerveux chez les invertèbres dans ses rapports avec la classification
de ces animaux. Paris, 1849.</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">in Cuvier’s Règne animal. (Edition accompagnée de planches gravées.
Insectes. Pl. 3, 3<i>a</i>, and 4.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Leidy, Joseph.</b> History and anatomy of the hemipterous genus Belostoma.
(Memoirs Amer. Acad. Arts and Sc., N. S. iv, 1849, pp. 57–67, 1 Pl.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Scheiber, S. H.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Vergleichende Anatomie und Physiologie der Œstridenlarven.
(Sitzungsb. k. Akad. wiss. Wien. Math.-Naturwiss. Cl., xli, 1860, pp. 439–496;
xlv, 1862, pp. 7–68; 5 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Tullberg, Tycho.</b> <span lang="sv" xml:lang="sv">Sveriges Podurider. (K. Svenska vet. Akad. Handl. x, 1872,
pp. 1–70, 12 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Berlese, A.</b> <span lang="it" xml:lang="it">Osservazione sulla anatomia descrittiva del <i>Gryllus campestris</i> L.
(Atti della soc. Veneto-Trentina, 1880, vii, pp. 200–299.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Baudelot, E.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Contributions à la physiologie der système nerveux des insectes.
(Revue d. sc. nat., i, pp. 269–280, 1872.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Studer, Th.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber Nervenendigung bei Insekten. Kleine Beiträge zur Histologie
der Insekten. (Mitt. Naturf. Ges., Bern, 1874, pp. 97–104, 1 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Brandt, E.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Recherches anatomiques et morphologiques sur le système nerveux
des insectes Hyménoptères. (Compt. rendus de l’Acad. Sc., Paris, 1875.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber das Nervensystem der Apiden. (Sitzungsb. d. naturf. Ges., in
Petersbourg, vii, 1876.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber das Nervensystem der Schmetterlingsraupen. (Verhandl. der Russ.
<span class='pageno' id='Page_247'>247</span>Ent. Gesellsch., x, 1877.</span> Also 16 other articles with plates, in Horæ Soc.
Ent. Ross., 1878–1882.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Mark, E. L.</b> The nervous system of Phylloxera. (Psyche, ii, pp. 201–207, 1879.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Riley, Charles Valentine.</b> The nervous system and salivary glands of Phylloxera.
(Psyche, ii, pp. 225, 226, 1879.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Cholodkowsky, N.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur Frage über den Baue und über die Innervation der
Speicheldrüsen der Blattiden. (Horæ Soc. Ent. Ross., 1881, xvi, pp. 6–9,
2 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Liénard, V.</b> <span lang="co" xml:lang="co">Constitution de l’anneau œsophagien. (Archives de Biologie, i,
pp. 381–391, 1880, 1 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Michaels, H.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Nervensystem von <i>Oryctes nasicornis</i> im Larven-, Puppen-, und
Käferzustande. (Zeits. f. wissens. Zool., xxxiv, 1880, pp. 641–702, 4 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Rossi, A.</b> <span lang="it" xml:lang="it">Sul modo di terminare dei nervi nei muscoli dell’ organo sonoro della
Cicala commune (<i>Cicada plebeja</i>). (Mem. accad. sc. Bologna, 1880, 4 Ser., i,
pp. 661–665.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Foettinger, A.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Sur le termination des nerfs dans les muscles des insectes.
(Archiv de Biologie, i, 1880.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Binet.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Contribution à l’étude der system nerveux sous intestinal des insectes.
(Journ. l’anat. et phys., xxx, pp. 449–580, 1894.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Paulowa.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zum Bau des Eingeweide Nervensystems der Insekten. (Zool.
Anzeiger., xviii, Feb. 25, 1895, pp. 85–87.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>Also the writings of Lyonet, Cuvier, Rolando, Straus-Durckheim, Leydig, Newport,
Graber, Viallanes, Grassi, Oudemans.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>b.</i> The brain</h4>

<p class='c017'><b>Dujardin, F.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Mémoires sur le système nerveux des insectes. (Annales des
Sciences nat, Sér. 3, 1850, xiv, pp. 195–206, Pl. 1, 1850.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Rabl-Rückhard.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Studien über Insectengehirne. (Archiv für Anatomie, Physiologie,
etc., herausg. von Reichert u. R. du Bois-Raymond, 1876, p. 480, Taf. i.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Dietl, M. J.</b> <span lang="lb" xml:lang="lb">Die Organization des Arthropodengehirns. (Zeitschr. wissens.
Zool., xxvii, 1876, p. 488, Taf. xxxvi.-xxxviii.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Flogel, T. H. L.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber den einheitlichen Bau des Gehirns in den verschiedenen

Taf. xxiii, xxiv.)</span></p>

insects, etc. (Journ. Quekett Microscopical Club, pp. 150–158, 1879.)</p>

Science, July, 1879, p. 340, Pl. xv, xvi.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Packard, A. S.</b> The brain of the locust. (Chapter xi, Second Report of the

<p class='c015'><b>Cuccati, Giovanni.</b> <span lang="co" xml:lang="co">Sulla stuttura del ganglio sopraesofageo di alcuni ortotteri.
(Acrydium lineola, Locusta viridissima, Locusta (species?), Gryllotalpa vulgaris,

<p class='c015'><b>Viallanes, H.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Études histologiques et organologiques sur les centres nerveux et

<p class='c015'><span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">1. Mémoire. Le ganglion optique de la langouste (<i>Palinurus vulgaris</i>).
