(Archiv f. Mikroscop. Anat., 1874, x, pp. 495–504, 1 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Spermatologische Beitrage: II. Mitteilung (Ibid., 1886, xxvii, pp. 1–122
Taf.). IV. Mitteilung (Ibid., 1886, xxviii, pp. 1–13, 4 Taf.) V. Mitteilung
(Ibid., 1887, xxx, pp. 426–434, 1 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Schneider, A.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Das Ei und seine Befruchtung, pp. 88, 10 Taf.; Arthropoden,
pp. 57–68 und 79. Taf. 8–10, 1883.</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Wielowiejski, H. de.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Observations sur la spermatogénèse des Arthropodes.
(Archiv Slav. de Biologie, 1886, ii, pp. 28–36.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Ballowitz, E.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur Lehre von der Struktur der Spermatozoen. (Anat. Anzeiger,
i Jahrg., 1886, pp. 363–376.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Untersuchungen über die Struktur der Spermatozoen, zugleiche in Beitrag
zur Lehre von feineren Bau der kontraktilen Elemente. Die Spermatozoen
der Insekten. I. Coleopteren. (Zeitschr. f. wissensch. Zool., 1, 1890, pp.
317–407, 4 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zu der Mittheilung des Herrn Professor L. Auerbach in Breslau über
merkwürdiger Vorgänger am Sperma von <i>Dytiscus marginalis</i>. (Anat.
Anzeiger, 1893, viii Jahrg., pp. 505–506.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Die Doppelspermatozoen der Dyticiden. (Zeitschr. f. wissensch. Zool.,
lxvi, 1895, pp. 458–499, 5 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Beauregard, H.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Note sur la spermatogénèse chez la cantharide. (Compt.-rend.
Soc. Biol., Paris, 1888, iv, pp. 331–333.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Gilson, G.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">Étude comparée de la spermatogénèse chez les Arthropodes, in La
Cellule, Recueil de Cytologie et d’Histologie gén., i, 1888, 8 Pl.</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Verson, E.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur Spermatogenesis. (Zool. Anzeiger, xii Jahrg., 1889, pp. 100–103,
Fig.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="co" xml:lang="co">La spermatogenesi nel <i>Bombyx mori</i>. (Padova, 1889, 25 pp. und 3 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur spermatogenesis. (Zool. Anzeiger, xii, 1889, pp. 100–103.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur spermatogenesis bei der Seidenraupe. (Zeitschr. f. wissens. Zool.,
lviii, 1894, pp. 303–313, 1 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Henking, H.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber Reductionsteilung der Chromosomen in den Samenzellen
von Insekten. (Internat. Monatsschr. f. Anat. und Phys., 1890, vii, pp.
243–248.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">I. Untersuchungen über die erste Entwicklungsorgänge in der Eiern der
Insekten. II. Ueber Spermatogenese und deren Beziehung zur Eientwickelung
bei <i>Pyrrhocoris apterus</i>. (Zeits. wissens. Zool., xlix, 1890, pp. 503–564;
li, 1891, pp. 685–736.) III. Specielles und Allgemeines. (Ibid., 1892, liv,
pp. 1–274, 12 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Sabatier, A.</b> <span lang="fr" xml:lang="fr">De la spermatogénèse chez les Locustides. (Comptes rend. Acad.
Paris, 1890, cxi, p. 797.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Cholodkowsky, N.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur Frage über die Anfangsstadien der Spermatogenese bei
den Insecten. (Zool. Anzeiger, 1894, pp. 302–304.) See also Zool. Anzeiger,
1892, p. 179.</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Auerbach, Leopold.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber merkwürdige Vorgänge am Sperma von <i>Dytiscus
marginalis</i>. (Sitz. Ber. Akad., Berlin, 1893, pp. 185–203, 2 Figs.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zu dem Bemerkungen des Herrn Dr. Ballowitz betreffend das Sperma von
<i>Dytiscus marginalis</i>. (Anat. Anzeiger, viii Jahrg., 1893, pp. 627–630.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Toyama, K.</b> On the spermatogenesis of the silkworm. (Bull, ii, No. 3, Coll.
Agric. Imp. Univ. Tokyo, pp. 125–157, 1894, 2 Pls.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Wilcox, E. V.</b> Spermatogenesis of <i>Caloptenus femur-rubrum</i> and <i>Cicada
tibicen</i>. (Bull. Mus. Comp. Zool., xxvii, 1895, pp. 32, 5 Pls.)</p>

<p class='c015'><span class='pageno' id='Page_513'>513</span>—— Further studies on the spermatogenesis of <i>Caloptenus femur-rubrum</i>.
(Ibid., xxix, 1896, pp. 193–202, 3 Pls.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Wilson, Edmund B.</b> The cell in development and inheritance. (New York,
1896.) Also the writings of Platner, Waldeyer.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>d.</i> On the paired genital efferent passages</h4>

<p class='c017'><b>Loew, H.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Abbildungen und Bemerkungen zur Anatomie einiger Neuropterengattungen.
(Linnæa Ent., 1848, pp. 345–385, 6 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Meinert, F.</b> <span lang="pl" xml:lang="pl">Anatomia Forficularum, i, Kjöbenhavn, 1863, 1 Pl.</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="da" xml:lang="da">Om dobbelte Saedgange hos Insecter. (Naturhist. Tidsskrift, 3 Raekke,
v, 1868, pp. 278–294.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Palmén, J. A.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur vergleichenden Anatomie der Ausführungsgänge der Sexualorgane
bei den Insekten. (Morph. Jahrb., ix, 1883, pp. 169–176.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'>—— <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Ueber paarige Ausführungsgänge der Geschlechtsorgane bei Insekten.
Eine morphologische Untersuchung. Helsingfors, 1884, pp. 108 und 5 Taf.</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Nusbaum, J.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Zur Entwicklungsgeschichte der Ausführungsgänge der Sexualdrüsen
bei Insekten. (Kosmos, Lemberg, 1884, ix Jahrg., pp. 256–266, 393–408,
462–474, 2 Taf. In Polish with résumé in German.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Spichardt, C.</b> <span lang="de" xml:lang="de">Beitrag zur Entwickelung der männlichen Genitalien und ihrer
Ausführgänge bei Lepidopteren. (Verhandl. d. naturwiss. Vereins zu Bonn,
1886, xliii Jahrg., pp. 1–34, 1 Taf.)</span></p>

<p class='c015'><b>Jackson, W. H.</b> Studies in the morphology of the Lepidoptera. I. (Zool.
Anzeiger, xii Jahrg., 1889, pp. 622–626.) (See p. 389.)</p>

<p class='c015'><b>Lowne, B. Th.</b> On the structure and development of the ovaries and their appendages
in the blow-fly (<i>Calliphora erythrocephala</i>). (Journ. Linn. Soc.
London, 1889, xx, pp. 418–442, 1 Pl.)</p>

<p class='c015'>See also Meinert (1897), Heymons (1897).</p>

<div class='nf-center-c0'>
<div class='nf-center c003'>
    <div>END OF PART I</div>
  </div>
</div>

<div class='chapter'>
  <span class='pageno' id='Page_515'>515</span>
  <h2 class='c005'>PART II. EMBRYOLOGY OF INSECTS</h2>
</div>

<h4 class='c011'><i>a.</i> The egg</h4>

<div  class='figright id031'>
<img src='images/i_537.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 482.</span>—Female Dyticus, laying eggs: <i>A</i>, ovipositor extended. <i>B</i>, egg of Notonecta, attached to stem of rush. <i>C</i>, egg of Dyticus, laid in excavation in rush.—After Régimbart, from Miall.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c016'>Insects as a rule arise from eggs which are laid in a great
variety of situations, those species which are viviparous being
exceedingly few in number compared with the class as a whole. It
is noteworthy that Leydig has found in the same Aphis, and even in
the same ovary, an
egg-tube producing
eggs, while a neighboring
tube was producing
viviparous
individuals.<a id='r77' /><a href='#f77' class='c012'><sup>[77]</sup></a> The
viviparous species are
confined to certain
May-flies, the Aphidæ,
Diptera (Sarcophaga,
Tachinidæ,
Œstridæ, and Pupipara),
and to certain
Coleoptera (Stylopidæ
and some Staphylinidæ).</p>

<p class='c007'>The number of eggs laid varies from a very few, as in the Collembola
and in the Psocidæ, or 15 or even less in certain fossorial wasps,
and from 20 to 35 in some locusts to many thousands in the social
insects, the honey-bee laying by estimate over 1,000,000 eggs in the
course of her life. Dr. Sharp thinks that from 50 to 100 may perhaps
be taken as an average number for one female to produce. The eggs
of insects with a complete metamorphosis are said by Brauer to be
smaller in proportion to the parent than those laid by ametabolous
or heterometabolous insects. In this respect the insects are paralleled
by the birds, the highest forms laying smaller eggs than the
water birds, ostrich, Apteryx, etc.</p>

<div  class='figleft id037'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_516'>516</span>
<img src='images/i_538a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 483.</span>—Eggs (<i>e</i>) of Hydrobius (?) and their capsules, from which the larva, Fig. 452, hatched.—Emerton <i>del.</i></p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The egg, or ovum, when laid is not always ripe or perfect, but, as
in those of ants, continues to grow after oviposition. Others are laid
some time after the embryo has begun
to form; and in the flesh-flies the larva
hatches before the egg is deposited.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id080'>
<img src='images/i_538b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 484.</span>—Egg-masses of Chironomus: <i>A</i>, string of eggs of <i>C. dorsalis</i>, divided into sections to show both sides. <i>B</i>, twisted fibres which traverse the string of eggs. <i>C</i>, egg-mass of Chironomus (<i>sp</i>). <i>D</i>, egg-mass of a third species. <i>E</i>, part of <i>D</i>, more highly magnified. <i>F</i>, developing eggs, two stages.—After Miall.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>Insects as a rule instinctively lay their
eggs near or upon objects destined to be
the food of the larva; those of caterpillars
on leaves, those of many flies on
meat or carrion, those of Copris and
other dung-beetles in dung, those of
aquatic insects in water, while many
oviposit in the earth or in plants (Fig.
482), or in the bodies of animals destined
to be the hosts of the parasitic larvæ.
As the eggs are preyed upon by mites and
other animals, the contrivances and modifications
of the mode of egg-laying, and
the situations in which they are placed, are almost endless. Many
insects lay their eggs in a mass, covered with a gummy substance;
<span class='pageno' id='Page_517'>517</span>or those laid in the water, as the eggs of dragon-flies, caddis-flies,
Chironomus (Fig. 484), etc., are enveloped by a jelly-like mass.</p>

<div  class='figright id012'>
<img src='images/i_539a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 485.</span>—Egg-capsule of <i>Periplaneta americana</i>: <i>a</i>, side; <i>b</i>, end view; <i>c</i>, natural size.—After Howard and Marlatt, Bull. 4, Div. Ent. U. S. Dept. Agr.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The <i>oötheca</i> of the cockroach (Fig. 485) is a solid, dense case, which,
after being carried about by the mother, can be left without harm in
the crevices of the floors of houses.
The oötheca of Mantis (Fig. 486) is
formed by a large mass of frothy
matter, which hardens and is attached
to stems of plants.</p>

<div  class='figleft id013'>
<img src='images/i_539b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 486.</span>—Egg-capsules of <i>Mantis carolina</i>.—After Riley.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>On the other hand, the female “walking-stick”
(<i>Diapheromera femoratum</i>)
drops her eggs, says Riley, loosely upon
the ground, from whatever height she may happen to be, and “one hears a
constant pattering, not unlike drops of rain, that results from the abundant
dropping of these eggs, which, in places, lay so thick among and under the
dead leaves that they may be scraped up in great
quantities.” (Report for 1879.)</p>

<p class='c007'>The eggs of the lace-winged flies are supported
on pedicels, above the reach of ovivorous
mites.</p>

<p class='c013'>The female Chrysopa usually lays between 40 and 50
eggs. In one case, we observed that 18 egg-stalks were
deposited, but there were only nine well-formed eggs in
the batch, and nine eggless stalks, some only half the
usual height, others with the knob of cement at the
end to which the egg is ordinarily fastened. The eggs
are evidently stuck on to the end of the pedicel after the
latter has been formed, as, in one instance, an egg was
glued to the stalk very much out of centre, the insect’s
abdomen not having been aimed straight, so to speak, at
the mass of cement.</p>

<div  class='figright id042'>
<img src='images/i_539c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 487.</span>—Eggs of Chrysopa, with larva and fly.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>The eggs of Rhodites are fixed to a long stalk thickened
at the end; those of Inquilines and certain Chalcids
(<i>Leucospis gigas</i>, Fig. 489, <i>A</i>) are also stalked; and the
use of this stalk in the eggs of Cynips (<i>E</i>) is thought
by Adler to be respiratory, while, also, he states that
the egg-cavity
communicates
with
the egg-stalk,
so
that a part
of the egg-contents
can pass into the latter,
and this happens at the laying of
each egg. The egg of certain ichneumons
(Paniscus, Fig. 488) ends
in a short stalk, which is inserted
<span class='pageno' id='Page_518'>518</span>in the skin of the caterpillar destined to serve as the host of the parasite, the
eggs, as stated by De Geer, being retained more firmly in the integument by
the stalk so swelling as to form two
knobs (Fig. 498, <i>c</i>).</p>

<div  class='figleft id007'>
<img src='images/i_540a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 488.</span>—Young larva of Paniscus in position of feeding on the skin of a caterpillar: <i>a</i>, the egg-shell.—After Newport, from Sharp.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>Certain Homoptera also have stalked
eggs, as those of <i>Psylla pyricola</i> (Fig.
489, <i>B</i>), those of <i>Aleyrodes citri</i> (<i>C</i>,
<i>a</i>, <i>b</i>), and of an allied form, <i>Aleurodicus
cocois</i> (<i>D</i>), and those of Corixa
(Fig. 493).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id102'>
<img src='images/i_540b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 489.</span>—Stalked eggs: <i>A</i>, of a Chalcid (after Fabre); <i>B</i>, of Psylla (after Slingerland); <i>C</i>, of Aleyrodes; <i>D</i>, of Aleurodicus (after Riley and Howard); <i>E</i>, of <i>Dryophanta scutellaris</i> (after Adler).</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id092'>
<img src='images/i_540c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 490.</span>—Eggs of ox bot-fly, enlarged.—After Riley.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>Reference should also be made to
the eggs of lice, which are oval and
attached to the hairs of their host. Those of the ox bot-fly (<i>Hypoderma lineata</i>)
are usually placed four to six together, and fastened to a hair. The lower portion
of the egg is admirably
adapted for clasping a
hair. “It consists of
two lobes, forming a
bulbous enlargement,
which is attached to
the egg by a broad, but
rather thin, neck, so
that, when the latter is
viewed sidewise, it appears
as a slender pedicel”
(Fig. 490, <i>a-d</i>).
(Riley in Insect Life,
iv, p. 307.) The egg of
another fly (<i>Drosophila ampelophila</i>, Fig. 491) bears a pair of long, slender appendages
near the anterior end. “The egg is inserted into the soft pulp of the
decaying fruit; these appendages leave the ovipositor last, and are spread out upon
the surface of the mass. They, in this way,
serve to keep the egg in place, and thus insure
the emergence of the larva into the open air
instead of into the more or less fluid mass in
which the egg is situated. The larva issues
from the egg just above the base of these appendages.”
(Comstock.)</p>

<div  class='figcenter id103'>
<img src='images/i_540d.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 491.</span>—Egg of Drosophila.—After Comstock.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>Mode of deposition.</b>—The
exact process
of oviposition has
been rarely observed,
or at least
not observed in detail,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_519'>519</span>and further observations are much needed. In the cockroach
(Phyllodromia), Wheeler has seen the eggs pass out of the oviduct
and become arranged in the oötheca, in a way similar to that in
the account published by Kadyi on Periplaneta.</p>

<div  class='figright id031'>
<img src='images/i_541.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 492.</span>—Rocky Mountain locust (<i>aa</i>) depositing its eggs (<i>c</i>); <i>d</i>, the earth partially removed, showing (<i>e</i>) an egg-mass already in place, and (<i>d</i>) one being placed; <i>f</i> shows where such a mass has been covered over. <i>A</i>, oviposition; <i>j</i>, position of oviduct; <i>g</i>, egg-guide; <i>e</i>, egg. <i>B</i>, egg-mass of the same; <i>a</i>, from side, <i>b</i>, from beneath, <i>c</i>, from above.—After Riley.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>“When about to form the capsule, the female Blatta closes the genital armature,
and the two folds of the white membrane which lines the oöthecal cavity
close vertically in the middle line. Then some of the contents of the colleterial
glands are poured into the chamber, and bathe the inner surface of the posterior
wall. The first egg glides down the vagina from the left ovary, describes an
arc, still keeping its germarium-pole uppermost, after having pressed the
micropylar area against the mouth of the spermatheca, passes to the right
side of the back of the chamber, and is placed perpendicularly two-thirds to
the right of the longitudinal axis of the insect’s body. The next egg comes
from the right ovary, describes an arc to the opposite side of the body, decussating
with the path of the first egg, and is placed completely on the left side of the
median line. The third
egg comes from the left
ovary, and is made to
lie completely on the
right side of the median
line; and so the process
continues, the ovaries
discharging the eggs
alternately, and each
egg describing an arc to
the opposite side of the
capsule. The oöthecal
chamber soon becomes
too small to contain all
the constantly accumulating
eggs, so the anal
armature opens and allows
the end of the capsule
to project. A raised
line, the impression of
the edges of the white
membrane, runs down
the end of the capsule.
The last egg deposited
comes from the right
ovary, and lies two-thirds
on the left, and one-third
to the right, of the
median line. As soon
as the egg is laid, a
further discharge from
the colleterial glands spreads over the vaginal or anterior wall of the cavity,
and becomes evenly continuous with the secretion which has before been
spread over the back and the sides of the capsule by the white membrane.</p>

<p class='c013'>“The crista, a cord-like ridge running the full length of the dorsal surface of
the capsule, is a thick-walled tube, either half of which is formed by the edge
of the side walls of the capsule split into two laminæ. The rhythmical clasping
<span class='pageno' id='Page_520'>520</span>of the three pairs of palpi which guard the vaginal opening is registered in an
exquisite pattern on the inner face of either half of the crista.”<a id='r78' /><a href='#f78' class='c012'><sup>[78]</sup></a></p>

<p class='c007'>The mode of oviposition in the locust has been fully described by
Riley, who states that the eggs pass down and out of the oviduct,
and “guided by a little finger-like style” (Fig. 298), they pass in
between the horny valves of the ovipositor, and issue at their tips
amid the mucous fluid which forms the egg-capsule (Fig. 492).</p>

<p class='c007'><b>Vitality of eggs.</b>—It is well known that the eggs of phyllopod
and other fresh-water Crustacea have wonderful vitality, withstanding
extreme dryness for several years, at least from two to ten.
Such cases are unknown among insects. It has been observed, however,
by T. W. Brigham, and also by L. Trouvelot, that the eggs of
the walking-stick (<i>Diapheromera femorata</i>) for the most part hatch
only after the interval of two years.<a id='r79' /><a href='#f79' class='c012'><sup>[79]</sup></a></p>

<p class='c007'>The eggs of Bittacus are said by Brauer to lie over unhatched for
two years; indeed, the first condition of their hatching is a complete
drying of the earth in which the eggs lie, the second is a succeeding
thorough wetting of the ground in spring.</p>

<p class='c007'><i>Appearance and structure of the ripe egg.</i>—The eggs of insects are
on the whole rather large in proportion to the size of the parent,
especially so in many minute forms, as the fleas, lice, etc.</p>

<p class='c007'>Their general shape is spherical or oval, often cylindrical; where
the eggs are long and cylindrical a dorsal and ventral side can be
distinguished (Fig. 502). They are in the Tortricidæ and Limacodid
moths flattened, thin, and scale-like. In the eggs of locusts and
grasshoppers, as well as certain Diptera, the ventral side of the
embryo corresponds to the convex side, and the concave side of the
egg to the dorsal region of the embryo (Figs. 502 and 493).</p>

<p class='c007'>There is an anterior and posterior end or pole, the anterior end
being that which in the body of the parent lies towards her head, or
towards the upper or distal end of the ovarian tube. Towards this
end lies in the later stages of embryonic life the head-end of the
embryo, while the posterior end of the embryo is turned towards the
hinder pole of the egg (Figs. 493 and 520).</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The egg-shell and yolk-membrane.</b>—The ripe egg is protected by
two membranes: 1, an inner or <i>vitelline membrane</i> or <i>oölemma</i> (<i>dh</i>)
(Fig. 500, <i>d</i>), produced in the egg by a hardening of the outer layer,
and 2, the outer or <i>chorion</i> (<i>c</i>), which is secreted by the cells of the
ovarian follicle. The latter is divided into two layers: an inner,
the <i>endochorion</i>, and an outer, the <i>exochorion</i>.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id065'>
<img src='images/i_543a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 503.</span>—Fertilization of the egg of a round-worm (<i>Ascaris megalocephala</i>): <i>A</i>, the ends (centrosomes) of the spindle formed. <i>B</i>, the spindle completed; <i>sp</i>, sperm-nucleus, with its chromosomes; <i>ei</i>, egg-nucleus; <i>p</i>, polar bodies.—After Boveri, from Field’s Hertwig.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figcenter id005'>
<img src='images/i_543b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 493.</span>—Eggs of Corixa: <i>A</i>, early stage before formation of the embryo, from one side. <i>B</i>, the same viewed in the plane of symmetry. <i>C</i>, the embryo in its final position; <i>a</i>, anterior, <i>p</i>, posterior, end; <i>l</i>, left, <i>r</i>, right, <i>v</i>, ventral, <i>d</i>, dorsal, aspect. (The letters refer to the <i>final</i> position of the embryo, which is nearly diametrically opposite to that in which it first develops); <i>m</i>, micropyle; <i>p</i>, pedicle.—After Metschnikoff, from Wilson.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id006'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_521'>521</span>
<img src='images/i_545a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 494.</span>—Eggs of Phasmidæ: <i>A</i>, <i>Lonchodes duivenbodi</i>. <i>B</i>, <i>Platycrania edulis</i>. <i>C</i>, <i>Haplopus grayi</i>. <i>D</i>, <i>Phyllium siccifolium</i>.—After Kaup, from Sharp.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>While the yolk-membrane is usually a completely homogeneous,
thin, structureless membrane, the chorion or shell of the egg is
usually covered with a network of ridges enclosing polygonal areas,
varying in shape according
to the species or
genus. These external
markings are due to the
impress of the cellular
structure of the epithelium
of the ovarian
follicle.</p>

<p class='c007'>In the chorion of the
cockroach the surface
appears to be finely
granular, the finest granules being arranged in large, more or less
regularly hexagonal areas, which are bounded by narrow, dark
spaces, containing somewhat larger though less dense granules. The
surface of the eggs of certain Phasmids are variously sculptured
(Fig. 494).</p>

<p class='c013'>The true structure of the chorion can only be, as Wheeler observes, seen in
cross-sections, as shown by Blochmann, and also by Wheeler. The chorion
consists of two chitinous laminæ kept in close apposition by means of numerous
minute trabeculæ or pillars. It is the ends of these pillars that look like granules.
In the spaces between the hexagonal areas, the trabeculæ are more
scattered and individually thicker than those of the hexagons.</p>

<div  class='figleft id093'>
<img src='images/i_545b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 495.</span>—Egg of cotton-worm moth, Aletia: <i>a</i>, top view, showing the micropyle.—After Comstock.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id014'>
<img src='images/i_545c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 496.</span>—Egg of <i>Danais archippus</i>.—After Riley.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>These markings are of singular beauty and complexity in the eggs
of many Lepidoptera, whose ova are variously ribbed, forming a
beautiful fretwork of raised lines (Figs. 495
and 496), while in the Diptera and Hymenoptera
the chorion is less solid, and
usually smooth under low
powers. The exochorion of the egg of the house and meat fly (<i>C.
vomitoria</i>) is pitted with elongated hexagonal depressions, which cross
the egg transversely. That of the honey-bee is also divided into
long hexagonal areas (Fig. 497).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id054'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_522'>522</span>
<img src='images/i_546a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 497.</span>—Egg with embryo of honey-bee, × 40: <i>ch</i>, chorion; <i>ga</i>, ganglia; <i>s. ga</i>, brain; <i>jm</i>, jaw-muscles forming; <i>c</i>, œsophageal collar; <i>fb</i>, fore intestine; <i>mb</i>, mid-intestine; <i>ab</i>, hind-intestine.—After Cheshire.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id023'>
<img src='images/i_546b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 498.</span>—Micropyle (<i>Mk</i>) of eggs; <i>a</i>, of a fly, Antomyia; <i>b</i>, <i>Drosophila cellaris</i>; <i>c</i>, stalked egg of <i>Paniscus testaceus</i>.—After Leuckart, from Perrier.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>When the eggs are deposited in exposed places, and remain in
such situations for several days, or weeks, or even through the
winter, the shell is either solid and strengthened by the ribs and
ridges; or the shell, if of winter eggs, is unornamented, and is dense
and solid, to resist extremes in temperature or the attacks of egg-eating
birds, mites, etc.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The micropyle.</b>—This is an opening or
canal, or, as in most insects, a group of
canals situated at the anterior end of
the egg for the entrance of the spermatozoa
during the process of fertilization
of the ovum (Fig. 498). In Acrydians,
however, the micropyle is situated
at the posterior end of the egg. The
micropyle (Fig. 499) is a complicated
apparatus within whose circumference
the vitelline membrane appears to be
firmly attached to the chorion, so that
the perforation passes through the chorion
as well as the yolk-membrane.</p>

<p class='c007'>The micropyles of the cockroach are
probably as simple and generalized as
in any insect. Wheeler states that they
are in Phyllodromia scattered over the
end of the egg, “over a quadrant of the
upper hemisphere, where the beautiful
hexagonal pattern of the chorion gives
away to an even trabeculation.” The
micropyles are wide-mouthed, very
oblique, funnel-shaped canals, perforating
the chorion, the apertures of the funnels
appearing under a low power as
<span class='pageno' id='Page_523'>523</span>clear, oval spots, the long axis of which is parallel to the long
axis of the egg.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id081'>
<img src='images/i_547a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 499.</span>—<i>a</i>, fragment of a micropylar papilla, showing its lumen; <i>b</i>, optical section of another papilla, in this one the lumen extends to the vitelline membrane, but does not pass beyond it; <i>c</i>, <i>d</i>, <i>e</i>, and <i>f</i>, papillæ of different forms. <i>A</i>, anterior end of an ovarian egg, showing mode of growth of the micropylar papillæ: <i>a</i>, <i>b</i>, two successive stages; <i>c</i>, surface view of modified papillæ from the lower edges of the cap; <i>d</i>, tunica propria of the ovariole; <i>e</i>, remnant of the cell-mass that secreted (?) the micropylar cap.—After Ayers.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figleft id013'>
<img src='images/i_547b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 500.</span>—Egg of <i>Perla maxima</i>: <i>c</i>, chorion; <i>d</i>, oölemma; <i>gs</i>, glass-like covering of micropyle; <i>l</i>, cavity under same; <i>g</i>, canals penetrating chorion.—After Imhof, from Sharp.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>“With a higher power the tube of each funnel is clearly visible as a thin
canal which dilates rapidly into the large oval aperture on the outer face of the
chorion. The narrow tube is sometimes fully as long as the large orifice. The
micropylar perforations are all directed from the germarium to the vaginal pole
of the egg. Hence a line, the hypothetical path of the spermatozoön, drawn
through one of these oblique micropyles, and continued into the egg, would
strike the equatorial plane. The female pronucleus, as we shall see further on,
moves in this plane.” (Wheeler, p. 289.)</p>

<div  class='figright id059'>
<img src='images/i_547c.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 501.</span>—Micropyles: <i>a</i>, of <i>Nepa cinerea</i>; <i>b</i>, of <i>Locusta viridissima</i>; <i>c</i>, of a bug (<i>Pyrrhocoris apterus</i>).—From Gerstäcker.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The micropylar region is generally, at least in Orthoptera and
Odonata, covered by a gelatinous cap (Figs. 499 and 500, <i>gs</i>), which
may form a covering membrane
which extends over a large part
of the egg, or may envelop the
entire outer surface. In some
cases micropyles are scattered
over the entire surface of the
egg, but usually the perforation
is situated at the end, and is
often guarded by raised processes,
either one or several, like
bristles, or toadstools, etc., these
being especially characteristic of
the eggs of certain Hemiptera (Nepa, Fig. 501, <i>a</i>, and Ranatra), or
the region is variously sculptured, as in the eggs of butterflies. In
the micropylar apparatus of Œcanthus the papillæ have a distinct
lumen (Fig. 499), or a channel for the ingress of the male filament.</p>

<div  class='figleft id023'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_524'>524</span>
<img src='images/i_548.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 502.</span>—Diagrammatic median section through egg of Musca in stage of fertilization (incorporating the figures of Henking and Blochmann): <i>ch</i>, chorion; <i>d</i>, dorsal; <i>v</i>, ventral side of the egg; <i>dh</i>, yolk-membrane; <i>do</i>, nutritive yolk; <i>g</i>, gelatinous cap over the micropyle (<i>m</i>); <i>K</i>, outer layer of plasma (Keimhautblastem); <i>p</i>, male and female pronucleus before copulation; <i>r</i>, directive body (Richtungskörper).—After Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>Another use of the micropylar apparatus noticed by Ayers in the
egg of the tree-cricket is that it “serves as a thick, roughened plate,
against which the insect may push when ovipositing, without injury
to the egg, and without danger that the ovipositor slips from its
place.” In Chrysopa eggs the micropyle
forms a conspicuous button-like
knob, resembling the finely
milled head of a certain kind of
screw.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>Internal structure of the egg.</b>—The
egg-contents are surrounded by
an outer layer of protoplasm or
formative yolk, which is separate
from the inner parts of the egg
(Fig. 502, <i>do</i>), the latter being
mostly composed of the nutritive
yolk-element. The superficial protoplasmic
layer, called by Weismann
<i>Keimhautblastem</i> (<i>K</i>) is, in
a few cases, afterwards entirely
lost, but in most instances forms a
very thin layer of clear protoplasm,
slight in extent compared with the
yolk-mass within.</p>

<p class='c007'>The eggs of insects are rich in
yolk, only certain eggs, such as those
of the Aphides and the egg parasites
(Proctotrypidæ) being poor in
yolk. The eggs of heterometabolous
insects have been said by
Brauer to contain relatively more
yolk than those of the Metabola,
particularly the Diptera; though,
as Wheeler observes, this rule has
some exceptions, the eggs of the
17–year Cicada being very numerous
and small.</p>

<p class='c013'>This he thinks is a greater advantage to the insect than the production of a
few large eggs, “when we consider the extremely long period of larval life and
the vicissitudes to which the larvæ may be subjected during all this time.”
“Similarly, <i>Meloë angusticollis</i> produces a large number of very small eggs,
while the eggs of the smaller beetles (Doryphora, <i>e.g.</i>) are much larger. But
<span class='pageno' id='Page_525'>525</span>Meloë is a parasitic form, and probably only a few of its many offspring ever
succeed in gaining access to the egg of the bee.”</p>

<p class='c007'>In the eggs of Chrysopa the yolk-granules are remarkably small,
so that the primitive band is in strong contrast to the yolk in color
and density. When crushed, the yolk does not flow out as a liquid,
but in a pasty mass, and we have questioned whether, as in the eggs
of Limulus, whose yolk is solid with fine granules, the denseness of
the yolk is not connected in the way of cause and effect with their
exposed situation.</p>

<p class='c007'>The central or yolk-mass (Fig. 502, <i>do</i>) consists chiefly of rounded
masses of yolk, with fat-globules, between which extends a fine network
of protoplasm.</p>

<p class='c007'>The elements of the yolk are spherical and strongly refractive, by
pressure becoming polygonal structureless homogeneous bodies.</p>

<p class='c007'>The germinal vesicle of the ripe insect-egg lies in the centre of the
yolk, where it appears as a large vesicle-like cell-nucleus containing
a few chromatin elements.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>b.</i> Maturation or ripening of the egg</h4>

<p class='c016'>Before the eggs of animals can be fertilized, they require in some
observed cases, and probably in animals in general, to undergo a
series of changes, which, as observed in the starfish, etc., consists in
the replacement of the germinal vesicle by a very much smaller egg-nucleus,
and also at the same time the construction at one pole of the
egg of the directive or polar bodies (Fig. 502, <i>r</i>). Towards the end
of the ripening process of the insect egg this vesicle, according to
Blochmann, passes to the dorsal surface of the egg, and is transformed
into the directive spindles (<i>Richtungspindel</i>).</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>c.</i> Fertilization of the egg</h4>

<p class='c016'>The egg next requires the penetration and admission into the
yolk-interior of a spermatozoön.</p>

<p class='c007'>This process is essentially in insects, as in other animals, the
fusion of the sperm-nucleus with the nucleus of the egg. Under
normal conditions but a single spermatozoön is required for fertilization.
As shown by Hertwig, in the sea-urchin, after the spermatozoön
has penetrated into the egg, the head, and the small rounded
body, called a <i>centrosome</i>, can still be recognized, but the tail becomes
fused with the yolk of the egg. In the protoplasm of the egg (called
<i>cytoplasm</i>) the achromatic end of the sperm-nucleus gives rise to
<span class='pageno' id='Page_526'>526</span>conspicuous rays, like those observed in ordinary cell-division. Preceded
by these rays, the sperm-nucleus or male pronucleus (Fig. 502, <i>p</i>)
moves towards the nucleus of the egg, and finally fuses with it, thus
forming a new single nucleus. This latter, which is called “the cleavage
nucleus,” rapidly forms a nuclear or “cleavage spindle” (Fig.
503). This act gives an impulse to the cleavage of the egg, which is
the first step in the formation of the embryo. All these changes
have yet to be worked out in detail in insects by microscopic sections
of the egg, whose generally hard and opaque egg-shells present
great obstacles to such work.</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>d.</i> Division and formation of the blastoderm<a id='r80' /><a href='#f80' class='c012'><sup>[80]</sup></a></h4>

<p class='c016'>In insects as in most other Arthropoda the segmentation of the
yolk is superficial and not total. The ovum is <i>centrolicithal</i>, <i>i.e.</i> the
yolk is concentrated at the centre of the egg, and surrounded by a
peripheral layer of transparent protoplasm (the <i>Keimhautblastem</i>).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id080'>
<img src='images/i_550.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 504.</span>—Formation of the blastoderm of <i>Pieris cratægi</i>: <i>A</i>, longitudinal section through the egg, with two masses of protoplasm in the yolk. <i>B</i>, a blastoderm-cell at the upper end. <i>C</i>, a later stage, with more blastoderm-cells.—After Bobretsky.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The first step in segmentation is the movement of the first division-nucleus
(<i>i.e.</i> that in the fertilized egg arising from the union of the
sperm-nucleus with the female pronucleus) towards the interior of
the egg in order to multiply itself by the mode of indirect nuclear
division (Figs. 504, <i>A</i>, and 507).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id008'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_527'>527</span>
<img src='images/i_551.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 505.</span>—Embryology of the mole-cricket: 1, egg in which the amœboid nuclei (<i>abc</i>) are moving toward the surface; 2, egg in which the nuclei (<i>abc</i>) have reached the surface, and show an active nucleus-formation; 3, the blastoderm-cells have no nucleus, and are placed at equal distances apart; 4, the blastoderm-cells now forming a continuous layer; 5, cross-section of the egg with blastodermic disk, also showing the disposition of the endodermal cells; 6, cross-section of the blastodermic disk, with the myoblast cells (<i>mb</i>) already formed; 7, cross-section through the thorax of the embryo, the body-cavity extended into the limbs.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div class='nf-center-c0'>
<div class='nf-center c031'>
    <div><span class='sc'>Lettering.</span></div>
  </div>
</div>

    </dd>

    </dd>

<div  class='figcenter id104'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_529'>529</span>
<img src='images/i_552.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 505</span> <i>concluded</i>.—Later stages in the embryology of the mole-cricket: 8, longitudinal section of the embryo; the yolk-pyramids (<i>yp</i>) form a common inner yolk-mass (<i>y</i>). 9, section through the heart; <i>H</i>, cavity of the heart; the two halves of the heart-sinuses having united dorsally, ventrally they are still open and are bounded by the walls of the mesenteron. 10, cross-section of an embryo, showing the blood-lacunæ separated on the back by the dorsal organ (<i>do</i>); the intestinal fasciated layer (<i>Darmfaserblatt</i>) has not completely enclosed the yolk. 11, embryo completely segmented, with the rudiments of the appendages, labrum (<i>lab</i>), and nervous ganglia (<i>pc-ng</i>). 12, a more advanced embryo, showing the stomodæum (<i>st</i>) indicated as a frontal protuberance. 13, section through the recently hatched larva, showing the cells of the mesenteron or chyle-stomach, and the cellular layer on the front surface, also the
proventriculus or crop.</p>
</div>

    </dd>

    <dd>subœsophageal ganglion.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>sm</i>,</dt>
    <dd>stomodæum.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>tg</i>,</dt>
    <dd>thoracic ganglion.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>vm</i>,</dt>
    <dd>ventral muscle.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>y</i>,</dt>
    <dd>yolk.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>yp</i>,</dt>
    <dd>yolk-pyramids.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>I</i>,</dt>
    <dd>1st pair of feet.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>II</i>,</dt>
    <dd>2d pair of feet.
    </dd>
    <dt><i>III</i>,</dt>
    <dd>3d pair of feet.
    </dd>
    </dl>

<div class='nf-center-c0'>
<div class='nf-center c031'>
    <div>—After Korotneff.</div>
  </div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The origin of numerous division-nuclei as the offspring of the first has been
observed to take place in the eggs of those insects (Aphides, Cecidomyia, and
Cynips) which have a slight amount of yolk. Yet in the large, ordinary eggs of
insects with an abundance of yolk there is no doubt, say Korschelt and Heider,
that these numerous division-nuclei, which soon after the process of oviposition
are scattered within the egg between the yolk-spheres, and are enveloped by a
star-shaped protoplasmic layer, and which constitute the formative elements
of the blastoderm,—there is no doubt but that they have practically arisen
through indirect nuclear division from the first division-nucleus.</p>

<p class='c007'>The process of formation of the blastoderm in ordinary eggs with abundant
yolk was first observed by Bobretsky in the eggs of a moth (Porthesia) and
Pieris, also by Graber, and more recently by Blochmann in Musca, and by
Heider in Hydrophilus.</p>

<p class='c007'>In the earliest stage observed by Bobretsky there first appear after fertilization
a few (the smallest number four) cell-like, minute amœboid masses of
protoplasm, each with a distinct nucleus. A few (one at least) of these bodies
gradually pass out of the centre of the yolk to the surface of the egg (Fig. 504,
<i>A</i>, <i>n</i>), these becoming larger and rounder, and from one or two of these nuclei
(<i>B</i>, <i>bc</i>) the blastoderm originates (<i>C</i>, <i>bl</i>). Those nuclei remaining in the yolk
increase in number and afterwards become the nuclei of rounded masses of yolk-granules,
forming the so-called yolk-spheres which Bobretsky regards as true cells.</p>

<p class='c007'>To the few blastoderm cells situated on the upper end of the egg are added
others which continue to pass from the yolk to the periphery, and then the
blastoderm spreads out farther and farther from the upper end of the egg until
finally it covers or envelops the whole yolk. This layer of cells is called the
<i>blastoderm</i>.</p>

<p class='c007'>As to the origin of the primitive amœboid cells, Bobretsky is in doubt, but is
disposed to think that they are the result of the subdivision of the germinative
vesicle or nucleus of the ovarian egg-cell. In this connection may be quoted the
observations of Graber, who states that an examination of the ovarian cell at an
early period has revealed the presence, in the centre of the yolk, of a number of
amœboid cells, which appear to have been formed by the division of the germinal
vesicle. These “primary embryonic cells” have a relatively large nucleus
and a number of nucleoli. Several may be seen to unite with one another by
means of their pseudopodia, and they may also be observed to undergo division.
With this account may be compared the results obtained by Korotneff in his
work on the embryology of the mole-cricket (Fig. 505).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id105'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_530'>530</span>
<img src='images/i_554.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 506.</span>—Four successive stages in the formation of the blastoderm of <i>Calliphora vomitoria</i> (the figures represent segments of cross-sections through the fly’s egg): <i>A</i>, the nuclei of the division-cells have arranged themselves parallel with the outer surface of the egg. <i>B</i>, the division-cells fused with the “keimhautblastem.” <i>C</i>, the outer surface becomes furrowed by indentations; all the nuclei of the blastoderm-cells in process of division. <i>D</i>, the blastoderm-cells form a high cylinder-epithelium: <i>b</i>, “keimhautblastem”; <i>bz</i>, blastoderm-cells; <i>d</i>, nutritive yolk; <i>dz</i>, yolk-cell; <i>fz</i>, so-called division-cell; <i>i</i>, inner “keimhautblastem.”—After Blochmann, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The result of these and of later observations, especially those of
Blochmann on Musca, and those of Heider on Hydrophilus, show
that the division-nuclei lie near
the centre of the egg, along the
longitudinal axis (Fig. 507, <i>A</i>).
Each of these nuclei is enveloped
by a star-shaped mass of protoplasm,
and on the whole resembles
a wandering amœboid cell.
These isolated masses of protoplasm
are all connected by a fine
network of rays, which unite to
form within the yolk a syncytium.
Afterwards, in the later
stages, these division-cells, as
they may be, though somewhat
incorrectly, regarded, move
nearer the periphery and arrange
themselves into a plane parallel
with the surface (Figs. 506, <i>A</i>,
507, <i>B</i>). Continuing to divide,
they reach the surface and fuse
with the peripheral protoplasmic
layer (Figs. 506, <i>B</i>, 507, <i>C</i>).
Then follows the division into
single cell-territories (Figs. 506,
<i>B</i>, 507, <i>C</i>), corresponding to the
division-nuclei, through the appearance
of furrows which pass
in from the outer surfaces of the
egg into the interior and gradually
penetrate the entire “keimhautblastem.”
In this way the
surface of the egg is covered with
an epithelium (blastoderm). In
many insects the so-called inner
“keimhautblastem” (Fig. 506,
<i>D</i>, <i>i</i>) is formed by the separation
of a layer of protoplasm which
contains larger granules and are accumulated between the blastoderm
and the upper surface of the central nutritive yolk-mass. By
the addition of this plasmic layer the cells of the blastoderm increase
<span class='pageno' id='Page_531'>531</span>in height, and now form a cubical or cylinder epithelium, which
continuously envelops the surface of the egg. (Korschelt and
Heider.)</p>

<h4 class='c011'><i>e.</i> Formation of the first rudiments of the embryo, and of the embryonic membranes</h4>

<div  class='figcenter id074'>
<img src='images/i_555.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 507.</span>—Formation of the blastoderm in Hydrophilus: <i>b</i>, completed blastoderm; <i>d</i>, yolk; <i>f</i>, so-called division-cells; <i>k</i>, “keimhautblastem”; <i>z</i>, yolk-cells.—After Heider, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c016'>The embryo first arises as a whitish streak or band-like thickening
on the ventral side of the egg, and is variously called the “primitive
streak,” “primitive band,” “germinal band,” or “embryonal streak.”
In most cases the primitive band is divided at regular intervals by
transverse furrows, indicating the limits of what are to be the body
segments.</p>

<p class='c007'>Cross-sections (Fig. 509) show that the band is composed of
several layers, <i>i.e.</i> an outer layer (ectoderm) and an inner layer
which comprises the endoderm and mesoderm, and so long as these
two layers are not sharply differentiated from one another, this
second layer may be called, with Kowalevsky, “the inner lower
layer, or ento-mesoderm” (Figs. 508, 509, <i>B</i>, <i>C</i>, <i>u</i>).</p>

<p class='c007'>It is characteristic of insects, only rarely occurring in other
arthropods (<i>e.g.</i> the scorpion), that the primitive streak is not situated
on the surface of the egg, but becomes overgrown by a folded
structure (Fig. 508, <i>af</i>) rising from its edges, the amnion-fold, so
<span class='pageno' id='Page_532'>532</span>that it appears somewhat depressed or sunken in under the upper
surface of the yolk. While the amnion-folds are extending from all
sides over the primitive band, there becomes formed under it, by the
invagination of the outer surface of the egg, a cavity, the amnion-cavity
(<i>ah</i>), which, when the amnion-fold has completely overgrown
the primitive band and united together (Fig. 509, <i>C</i>), appears completely
closed from without.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id038'>
<img src='images/i_556.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 508.</span>—Two schematic median sections through an insect-embryo to represent the development of the embryonal membranes. In <i>A</i> the primitive streak is not wholly overgrown by the amnion-fold. In <i>B</i> the amnion-folds have united with each other and completely overgrown the primitive streak: <i>a</i>, fore, <i>b</i>, hind, egg-pole; <i>v</i>, ventral side; <i>d</i>, dorsal side; <i>af</i>, amnion-folds; <i>ah</i>, amnion-cavity; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>do</i>, yolk; <i>ec</i>, ectoderm; <i>k</i>, head-end, <i>k′</i>, hinder-end, of the primitive streak; <i>s</i>, the part of the serosa arising from the amnion-fold; <i>s′</i>, the part of the serosa arising from the unaltered blastoderm; <i>u</i>, lower layer.—After Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>Formation of the embryonic membranes.</b>—The amnion-folds finally
completely overgrow the primitive band (Fig. 509, <i>B</i> and <i>C</i>), and
form the embryonal membranes. The primitive band is seen after
its completion to be overgrown by a double cellular epithelial
membrane. The outer of these two membranes, that which arises
from the outer leaf or layer of the amnion-fold, is the <i>serosa</i> (Figs.
508, <i>B</i>; 509, <i>C</i>, <i>s</i>; 510). This passes continuously into the unchanged
part of the blastoderm, which has no part in the formation of the
<span class='pageno' id='Page_533'>533</span>primitive band and germ-layers, and which covers the outer surface
of the yolk. Thus the <i>serosa</i>, which is usually held to include this
portion also of the blastoderm,
forms a closed sac which covers
the whole surface of the egg, with
one part extending over the surface
of the yolk, and the other over the
primitive band (Fig. 510).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id081'>
<img src='images/i_557.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 509.</span>—Diagrammatic cross-section through three successive stages of the primitive streak, and growing embryonal membranes of insect-embryos. <i>A</i>, formation of the ventral plate and of the gastrula invagination (<i>g</i>). <i>B</i>, upward growth of the amnion-folds (<i>af</i>). <i>C</i>, complete overgrowth of the primitive band through the amnion-folds: <i>v</i>, ventral side; <i>d</i>, dorsal side; <i>af</i>, amnion-folds; <i>ah</i>, amnion-cavity; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>bl</i>, blastoderm; <i>bp</i>, ventral plate; <i>do</i>, yolk; <i>ec</i>, ectoderm; <i>s</i>, serosa; <i>u</i>, under or inner layer.—After Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The inner of the two layers,
called the <i>amnion</i> (Fig. 509, <i>am</i>),
is more closely connected with the
embryo. The amnion and ectoderm
of the primitive band together
form a completely closed
sac, whose lumen forms the
amniotic cavity. Originally connected
with the serous membrane,
it splits off from the primitive
band about the time the appendages
begin to bud out, and continues
to closely envelop the body
and appendages, as seen in Fig.
509. Both of these membranes
are, before the time of hatching,
either absorbed, or, as in Lepidoptera,
retained. The amnion is
retained until after hatching in
the locust, etc. In certain Coleoptera
the serosa is retained, and the
amnion is absorbed (Fig. 532),
while in Chironomus and the
Trichoptera the serosa is absorbed,
and the amnion retained,
with the egg-shell or chorion.
<span class='pageno' id='Page_534'>534</span>Hence we have eight layers in the winged insects<a id='r81' /><a href='#f81' class='c012'><sup>[81]</sup></a> during embryonic
life:</p>

<div  class='figcenter id106'>
<img src='images/i_558.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 510.</span>—Surface view of fresh serosa from an Œcanthus, treated with acetic carmine; the blastoderm completely formed, × 500: <i>p</i>, polar body; <i>rf</i>, radiating fibres; <i>nls</i>, nuclear substance; <i>nlm</i>, nuclear membrane.—After Ayers.</p>
</div>
</div>

  <dl class='dl_3'>
    <dt>&nbsp;</dt>
    <dd>1. Exochorion. (Remains of the epithelium of the ovarian follicle.) 2. Chorion. 
    (Egg-shell or cuticle secreted in the ovarian follicle.) 3. Vitelline membrane. (Primary 
    egg-membrane. Yolk-skin or membrane.) 4. Serous or outer germ-membrane. (Serosa.)  } 5. 
    Amnion or inner germ-membrane.            }  Derived from the blastoderm. 6. Ectoderm.  } 
                                 } 7. Mesoderm.  } Embryo.                      } 8. 
    Endoderm.  }                              }
    </dd>
    </dl>

<p class='c013'>In the embryo of Xiphidium and Orchelimum Wheeler has found and described
with much detail a membranous structure which he calls the <i>indusium</i>. “The
organ,” he says, “appears to have been retained by the Locustidæ, and completely
lost by the embryos of other winged insects.” It arises in Xiphidium,
as a simple circular thickening of the blastoderm, between and a little in front
of the procephalic lobes (Figs. 511, 512, <i>A-E</i>), and afterwards spreads over nearly
the whole surface of the egg, leaving the poles uncovered, as in Fig. 513, where it is
divided into two further membranes, the inner and outer indusium, the former
lying in contact with the amnion. After this the serosa “is excluded from
taking any part in the development of the embryo; both its position and function
are now usurped by the inner indusium.”</p>

<p class='c013'><span class='pageno' id='Page_535'>535</span>Hence in an egg of the Locustidæ Wheeler distinguishes, passing from within
outward in a median transverse section of the egg, the following envelopes:</p>

  <dl class='dl_4'>
    <dt>&nbsp;</dt>
    <dd>1. The chorion. 2. The blastoderm-skin-like cuticle secreted by the serosa. 3. The 
    serosa. 4. The outer indusium. 5. A layer of dark granular secretion (probably some 
    urate). 6. The cuticle secreted by the inner indusium. 7. The inner indusium. 8. The 
    amnion. While envelopes 1–7 invest the whole egg; layer 8, the amnion, covers only the 
    embryo.
    </dd>
    </dl>

<div  class='figcenter id065'>
<img src='images/i_559.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 511.</span>—Diagrams illustrating the movements and envelopes of the embryo of Xiphidium: <i>A</i>, after the closure of the amnioserosal folds. <i>B</i>, during the embryo’s passage to the dorsal surface. <i>C</i>, just after the straightening of the embryo on the dorsal surface; <i>ind</i>, indusium afterwards forming <i>ind<sup>1</sup></i>, the inner, and <i>ind<sup>2</sup></i>, the outer indusium; <i>ch</i>, chorion; <i>sr</i>, serosa; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>gb</i>, germ-band; <i>v</i>, yolk; <i>bl. c</i>, blastoderm membrane.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>Wheeler further suggests that the so-called micropyle of the Collembola
(Anurida), which has been homologized with the “dorsal organ” of Crustacea,
is a possible homologue of the indusium, as also the “primitive cumulus” of
spiders, and the “facette” or “cervical cross” of Pentastomids described by
Leuckart and also by Stiles.</p>

<p class='c007'><b>The gastrula stage.</b>—The primitive band invaginates so as to give
the opportunity for the formation of the inner layer. This invagination,
which at a certain stage is established along the whole
length of the primitive band, forms a median furrow and may be
<span class='pageno' id='Page_536'>536</span>regarded as the gastrula-invagination of insects. The lower (inner)
layer thus arising afterwards spreads out under the entire primitive
band (Fig. 509, <i>B</i> and <i>C</i>), the edges of which become bordered
by the growing amnion-fold. (Korschelt and Heider.)</p>

<p class='c013'>In certain forms the primitive band arises from several separate rudiments
which afterwards unite. Thus in Musca and Hydrophilus the anterior and posterior
ends develop first, and in Hydrophilus the procephalic lobes originate
independently of the rest of the band. In the Aphides, also, according to Will,
these lobes arise independently, afterwards uniting with the primitive band.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id060'>
<img src='images/i_560.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 512.</span>—Diagrams illustrating the movements and envelopes of the embryo of Xiphidium: <i>D</i>, the stage of the shortened embryo on the the dorsal yolk. <i>E</i>, embryo returning to the ventral surface. <i>F</i>, embryo nearly ready to hatch; <i>ch</i>, chorion; <i>b. lc</i>, blastoderm membrane; <i>sr</i>, serosa; <i>ind<sup>1</sup></i>, outer indusium; <i>ind<sup>2</sup></i>, inner indusium; <i>ind<sup>2</sup> + am</i>, inner indusium and amnion fused; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>ind<sup>1</sup> c</i>, cuticle of the inner indusium; <i>ind<sup>2</sup> s</i>, granular secretion of the inner indusium; <i>am. s</i>, amniotic secretion; <i>v</i>, yolk; <i>cl</i>, columella; <i>gb</i>, primitive band.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>Division of the embryo or primitive band into body-segments.</b>—Meanwhile
the primitive band grows at the expense of the yolk, spreading
out more and more over its surface, until in certain cases
(Coleoptera, Diptera, Siphonaptera, and Trichoptera) it lies like a
broad ribbon over the yolk, so that the two ends nearly meet on the
dorsal side. By this time it becomes divided by transversely impressed
lines into segments, which correspond to those of the larva
and adult. The first of these segments is divided into two broad
<span class='pageno' id='Page_537'>537</span>and flaring flaps, which are called the procephalic lobes. It
becomes the antennal segment.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id048'>
<img src='images/i_561a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 513.</span>—Two stages in the spreading of the indusium. <i>A</i>, lateral view of egg just after the arrival of the embryo on the dorsal yolk. <i>B</i>, lateral view of the egg with the indusium nearly reaching the poles. <i>C</i>, same egg seen from the dorsal surface.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>The mouth (<i>stomodæum</i>) now develops, and is situated at the
anterior,<a id='r82' /><a href='#f82' class='c012'><sup>[82]</sup></a> and the rectum (<i>proctodæum</i>,) at the posterior pole, or end
of the primitive band.</p>

<div  class='figright id037'>
<img src='images/i_561b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 514.</span>—Median section of the egg of <i>Anurida maritima</i>: <i>do</i>, “micropyle”; <i>bld</i>, blastoderm.—This and Figs. 511–513, after Wheeler.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In Blatta, Hydrophilus, the Trichoptera,
and the Lepidoptera the hindermost
part of the primitive band is turned in
ventrally (Figs. 534, <i>C</i>).</p>

<p class='c013'>The preceding account of the relations of the
primitive band to the yolk does not apply to all
insects, since there are variations which appear
to depend on the form of the egg, and on the
amount and distribution of the yolk-masses. In
certain Coleoptera, the primitive band sinks down
and thus becomes immersed into the yolk. In
Donacia (Kölliker and Melnikow) and Hydrophilus
(Heider), and in the Chrysomelidæ and
<span class='pageno' id='Page_538'>538</span>Attelabus, a weevil, as we have observed, the primitive band rests on the
outside of the yolk, but in <i>Telephorus fraxini</i> it is immersed. In the Hemiptera
it is immersed (Fig. 516), but there is much variation in this respect, the degree
of immersion being most marked in the Coccidæ (Aspidiotus), and least so in
Corixa. Besides the position of the primitive band,
there are in Odonata and Hemiptera differences in
the origin of the primitive band itself and of the
embryonic membranes.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id008'>
<img src='images/i_562a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 515.</span>—Ventral view of five developmental stages of Hydrophilus: <i>a</i> and <i>b</i>, places at which the blastopore contracts; <i>af</i>, edge of the amnion-fold; <i>af′</i>, caudal fold; <i>af″</i>, paired head-fold of the amnion; <i>an</i>, antenna; <i>es</i>, last segment; <i>g</i>, pit-like invagination (first indication of the amniotic cavity); <i>k</i>, head-lobes; <i>r</i>, furrow-like invagination; <i>s</i>, portion of the primitive streak covered by the amnion.—After Heider, from Lang.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id037'>
<img src='images/i_562b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 516.</span>—Embryo of the louse: <i>am</i>, serosa; <i>db</i>, amnion; <i>as</i>, antenna; <i>vk</i>, clypeus.—After Melnikow.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>Korschelt and Heider divide the early embryo of
insects into two types:</p>

<p class='c013'>1. Into those with a superficial primitive band;
viz., where there is no passage of yolk-elements into
the space between the amnion and serosa. The
primitive band has in such cases a relatively superficial
position (Figs. 508, 509, 521, 535). Examples
are certain Orthoptera (Blatta, Œcanthus, Mantis,
Gryllotalpa), also certain Hemiptera (Corixa), certain
Coleoptera, and the Trichoptera, Diptera, and
Hymenoptera.</p>

<p class='c013'>2. Into those with an immersed primitive band,
with the space between the serosa and amnion
filled with yolk (Figs. 517, 518, 534). Examples
are the orthopterous Stenobothrus, Odonata, many
Hemiptera (the Pediculina and Pyrrhocoris), the
Coleoptera already mentioned, and Lepidoptera.</p>

<p class='c013'>It should be observed, however, that these differences
are of little phylogenetic or taxonomic value,
since genera of the same order, notably the Coleoptera,
differ as to the position of the primitive band,
so also two orders so nearly allied as the Trichoptera
and Lepidoptera.</p>

<p class='c013'><b>Differences between the invaginated and overgrown primitive band.</b>—In
respect to the mode of origin of the primitive band and its relative position,
<span class='pageno' id='Page_539'>539</span>there are two opposite types, though connected by transitional forms. In
the one case the primitive band, <i>i.e.</i> its ventral portion, the “ventral plate”
(Fig. 518, <i>b</i>, <i>p</i>) is pushed in or invaginated in the interior of the egg; in the
other case it becomes overgrown by the folds of the amnion arising from its
edges.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id054'>
<img src='images/i_563a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 517.</span>—Primitive streak of a lepidopter in cross-section: <i>ah</i>, amniotic cavity; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>c</i>, cœlomic cavity; <i>do</i>, nutritive yolk, divided into single nucleated masses; <i>ec</i>, ectoderm; <i>m</i>, mesoderm; <i>pr</i>, primitive thickenings of the ventral nervous cord; <i>s</i>, serosa.—Combined figure after those of Brobretsky and Hatschek, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figcenter id078'>
<img src='images/i_563b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 518.</span>—Five diagrammatic median sections representing the growth of a dragon-fly (Calopteryx). <i>A-C</i>, development of the primitive streak (<i>k</i>, <i>k′</i>) by invagination. <i>D</i>, the amnion-fold (<i>af</i>), growing over the head-end of the primitive streak. <i>E</i>, closing of the opening of the amnion-cavity (<i>ah</i>): <i>v</i>, ventral, <i>d</i>, dorsal side; <i>a</i>, fore, <i>b</i>, hind end of egg; <i>bl</i>, blastoderm; <i>bp</i>, ventral plate; <i>do</i>, yolk; <i>k</i>, head-end, <i>k′</i>, caudal end, of the primitive streak; <i>kh</i>, germinal thickening or initial point of invagination; <i>s</i>, serosa.—After Brandt, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>In insects with an overgrown primitive band, the band at the beginning is
generally short and always situated on the ventral side of the egg, with the
head-end looking forward, and remains in this position throughout embryonic
<span class='pageno' id='Page_540'>540</span>life. There is no revolution
of the embryo. The embryonal
membranes arise through
the formation of folds.</p>

<div  class='figleft id018'>
<img src='images/i_564a.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 519.</span>—Three embryonic stages of Calopteryx: <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>g</i>, edge of the ventral plate; <i>ps</i>, germ of primitive band; <i>se</i>, serosa.—After Brandt, from Balfour.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div  class='figright id021'>
<img src='images/i_564b.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 520.</span>—Three farther stages of growth of Calopteryx. <i>B</i> and <i>C</i> show the inversion of the embryo: <i>a</i>, opening of the amniotic-cavity, out of which the embryo emerges; <i>ab</i>, abdomen; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>at</i>, antenna; <i>md</i>, mandible; <i>mx<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>mx<sup>2</sup></i>, 1st and 2d maxillæ; <i>œ</i>, œsophagus; <i>p<sup>1</sup></i>, <i>p<sup>2</sup></i>, <i>p<sup>3</sup></i>, legs; <i>se</i>, serosa; <i>v</i>, anterior end of the primitive streak.—After Brandt, from Balfour.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>In insects with an invaginated
primitive band, of which
the Odonata afford examples,
the first rudiment of the
primitive band is in the form
of a ventral plate of slight
extent passing ventrally in
the hinder half of the egg, in
whose posterior section a process
of invagination (Fig. 518,
<i>A</i>, <i>kh</i>), soon occurs. The
cavity of this invagination is
the first indication of the
amnion-cavity (Fig. 518, <i>B</i>,
<i>ah</i>), while its wall in its
thickened ventral part (<i>K′</i>) is
concerned in the formation of
the primitive band, and, in its
dorsal thin part, in the formation
of the amnion (<i>B</i>, <i>C</i>, <i>am</i>).</p>

<p class='c013'><b>Revolution of the embryo
where the primitive band is
invaginated.</b>—At first the
head-end of the embryo is
directed towards the posterior
end of the egg, as in dragon-flies
(Fig. 518). Also that
surface of the primitive band
which afterwards faces the
ventral, is at first turned
towards the dorsal side of the
egg. In order to bring the
primitive band into the later
relations, there must occur
the process of revolution, or
turning, of the embryo. The
somewhat advanced embryo
of the Odonata, after the appearance
of the head and
thoracic appendages, undergoes
a rotating motion around
its transverse axis, and at the
same time turns out of the
amniotic cavity (Fig. 520, <i>B</i>).
This process is so managed
that near the head-region, the
amnion and serosa, there
closely situated to each other,
are fused together, and at this
<span class='pageno' id='Page_541'>541</span>place tear or burst open. Through this rent (<i>a</i>), in the same place in which
the original invagination-opening was situated, the amniotic cavity again opens,
and through the opening thus formed first the head and then the succeeding
segments of the primitive band (Fig. 520, <i>B</i>) pass out, and remain there while
the head passes on to the anterior pole of the egg on the ventral side, the embryo
thus assuming a position like that of other insects. (Kowalevsky.)</p>

<p class='c013'>In the parasitic Hemiptera (Pediculina), according to Melnikow, the opening
in the membranes near the head remains permanent, and the embryo becomes
everted through it, while the yolk, enclosed in the continuous membrane formed
by the amnion and serous membrane, forms a yolk-sac on the dorsal surface.
The same process occurs in Mallophaga, and also in Œcanthus, as described by
Ayers (Fig. 521). Generally as soon as the embryo passes out of the amniotic
cavity the latter soon becomes smaller and finally completely disappears.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id078'>
<img src='images/i_565.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 521.</span>—Revolution of the embryo of Œcanthus (diagrammatic): <i>a</i>, fore, <i>b</i>, hind end of egg; <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>d</i>, dorsal, <i>v</i>, ventral side of egg; <i>k</i>, primitive streak; <i>r</i>, dorsal plate (originating by the contraction of the serosa (<i>s</i>)).—After Ayers, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c013'>As the embryo grows, and the sides grow up and the back closes over, the
contents of the yolk-sac are soon taken up and absorbed in the intestinal cavity,
which communicates with it.</p>

<p class='c013'>In Phyllodromia, according to Wheeler, the process of revolution is “hurried
through by the embryo from the beginning of the 16th to the end of the 17th
day.” Several successive stages are represented in Fig. 522. In the 15th day
the embryo still occupies the middle of the ventral surface of the egg. Soon the
envelopes (amnion and serosa, <i>as</i>) rupture, an irregular slit being formed, and
soon the egg and embryo are as seen in Fig. 522, <i>B</i>, the embryo standing out free
from its envelopes on the yolk, and the edges of its dorsal growing walls (<i>b</i>) are
distinctly marked. The tail now lies at the caudal end of the egg (Fig. 522, <i>C</i>).
By the 17th day the walls have closed in the median dorsal line, and the embryo
has grown in length to such an extent as to bring its head to the cephalic
pole (Fig. 522, <i>E</i>).</p>

<p class='c013'>Korschelt and Heider consider, since the primitive band of the chilopod myriopods
(Geophilus) is curved in at the middle and sinks into the interior of the
<span class='pageno' id='Page_542'>542</span>yolk, that in insects the invaginated primitive band is the ancestral or primitive
one, the overgrown primitive band being derived from it. The overgrown
primitive band by its position may also be better insured against certain mechanical
attacks, perhaps also against the danger of drying up.</p>

<div  class='figcenter id005'>
<img src='images/i_566.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 522.</span>—Embryo of Phyllodromia, 15 days old; revolution about to begin. The stages in revolution are represented, after the rupture of the amnion and serosa, in <i>A</i> to <i>E</i>, which are from embryos 16, 16½, 16¾, and 17 days old respectively: <i>as</i>, amnion and serosa; <i>s</i>, edge of serosa; <i>b</i>, dorsal growing body-wall; <i>d.o</i>, dorsal organ; <i>x</i>, clear zone covered with scattered amniotic nuclei.—After Wheeler.</p>
</div>
</div>

<h4 class='c011'><i>f.</i> Formation of the external form of the body</h4>

<p class='c016'><b>Origin of the body-segments.</b>—As we have seen, the first traces of
segments appear very early, the primitive band being divided
by superficial transverse furrows into segments. This segmentation
into arthromeres (somites or metameres) can be observed in
Hydrophilus and Chalicodoma at a time when gastrulation begins
(Figs. 515, 536). The segmentation extends not only across the
median portion of the primitive band, through whose invagination
the inner layer (endomesoderm) results, but also to the lateral portions
which become a part of the ectoderm of the primitive band.
These transverse furrows correspond to thinner places in the epithelium,
which in this stage forms the embryonal rudiment. It thus
happens that, in the forms named, after the end of gastrulation not
only the ectoderm, but also the endomesoderm, is already segmented.</p>

<p class='c013'>So early an appearance of segmentation as that observed in Hydrophilus and
Chalicodoma we must regard as a falsification of the process of development
due to heterochrony. We must consider the conditions observed in other forms
as the primitive ones, in which (as, for example, in Lina and in Stenobothrus,
according to Graber) the gastrulation and separation of the ectoderm occurs in
the still unsegmented primitive band, the division into segments occurring in
later stages (Fig. 524). In these forms, then, the segmentation affects the
invaginated endomesoderm, as well as the ectoderm. (Korschelt and Heider,
p. 789.)</p>

<div  class='figcenter id107'>
<span class='pageno' id='Page_543'>543</span>
<img src='images/i_567.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 523.</span>—Diagrammatic cross-section through three successive stages of Gryllotalpa, showing the formation of the heart. (Compare Fig. 505.) The germs of the glandular intestinal layer (<i>darmdrüsenblatt</i>) are omitted. <i>A</i>, earliest stage; the primitive streak extends from <i>*x</i> to <i>y*</i>. The embryonal membranes are torn and pressed against the back: <i>am</i>, edge of the rent; <i>rp</i>, dorsal plate (serosa); <i>l</i>, lamella (amnion turned up) standing in connection with the ectoderm of the primitive streak. <i>B</i>, second stage; the primitive streak has completely grown around the yolk; the dorsal organ is absorbed. <i>C</i>, third stage, dorsal portion; the formation of the heart is finished: <i>am</i>, vestige of the amnion-fold; <i>bs</i>, blood-sinus; <i>dd</i>, rudiment of the dorsal diaphragm; <i>dv</i>, ventral diaphragm (compare Fig. 505); <i>do</i>, yolk; <i>dz</i>, yolk-cells; <i>ec</i>, ectoderm; <i>gr</i>, vascular groove (rudiment
of the heart); <i>l</i>, lamella of the upturned amnion; <i>lh</i>, definite body-cavity; <i>m</i>, transverse muscle; <i>n</i>, nervous cord; <i>r</i>, heart; <i>rp</i>, dorsal plate; <i>sp</i>, splanchnic; <i>so</i>, somatic layer of the mesoderm; <i>us</i>, primitive segmental cavity; <i>*x</i>, <i>y*</i>, lateral terminations of the primitive streak.—After Korotneff, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'>In the completely segmented primitive band may be distinguished
two regions of a peculiar appearance (Figs. 515, 527), one at the
anterior, and the other at the hinder end. The anterior, the primary
head-section, contains the mouth-opening, and is characterized
by its lateral expansions, or procephalic lobes. The other section,
or posterior section, the so-called anal segment or telson, contains
the anus. Between the two sections lies the segmented primary
trunk-segment, which in insects consists of 17 segments. Of these
the three most anterior are those destined to bear the mandibles and
two pairs of maxillæ; the three following are the thoracic, which
are succeeded by 10 abdominal segments, besides the 11th or telson
(pygidium, or suranal plate).</p>

<p class='c013'><span class='pageno' id='Page_544'>544</span>It is now generally believed that there are primarily eleven abdominal segments,
while Heymons has detected twelve in the embryos of Blattids and
Forficula (see p. 162). In the later stages of embryonic development the number
of abdominal segments is diminished, the 10th and 11th abdominal segments
becoming fused. In Hydrophilus and Lina this is the case, but according to
Graber, in the Lepidoptera there is a fusion of the 9th and 10th abdominal segments,
the llth remaining free.</p>

<p class='c013'>According to Wheeler, in Doryphora, and also in Chalicodoma (Carrière),
between the primary head-region and the mandibular segment is interpolated a
rudimentary and transitory body-segment, the premandibular segment. According
to Carrière this segment corresponds to a rudimentary pair of limbs,
and also to a ganglion, which participates in the formation of the œsophageal
commissure (see p. 51).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id094'>
<img src='images/i_568.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 524.</span>—Three embryonic stages of a leaf-beetle (Lina): <i>A</i>, unsegmented primitive streak; in <i>B</i> and <i>C</i> the segmentation becomes distinct on the lower layer (<i>u</i>). <i>B</i>, with the germs of the gnathal segments (<i>k′-k‴</i>), and in <i>C</i> the three thoracic segments (<i>t’-t‴</i>), with the first two abdominal segments (<i>a</i>′, <i>a″</i>): <i>bl</i>, blastopore; <i>kl</i>, head-lobes; <i>th</i>, extension of the primitive streak into the thoracic region.—After Graber, from Korschelt and Heider.</p>
</div>
</div>

<p class='c007'><b>The procephalic lobes.</b>—The head-lobes, or procephalic lobes, appear
at a very early period (Fig. 524, <i>kl</i>), before any traces of the
segments of the trunk region. Ayers has shown that in Œcanthus
the primitive band, in its earliest condition and before the appearance
of the head-lobes, is a simple oval plate or almond-shaped
thickening near the posterior end of the egg (Fig. 525, <span class='small'>1</span>, <span class='small'>2</span>). This
plate is “soon divided into two tolerably well-marked regions by
the enlargement of the head-end,” the first indication of the head-lobes
<span class='pageno' id='Page_545'>545</span>(<span class='small'>3</span>). A depression next forms in what is to be the middle of
the forehead. “It indicates the position of the future labrum, and
forms the inner boundaries of the two cephalic ganglia, which are
developed on either side of this depression at a much later stage.”
Almost simultaneously with the appearance of this depression, two
lateral folds are formed in the trunk portion of the band, which are
the first indications of the maxillary and thoracic regions, the
abdominal portion not yet showing traces of a division into segments
(Fig. 525, <span class='small'>5</span>). The thickened outer edges of the head-fold
next gradually grow in towards the median line (Fig. 525, <span class='small'>5</span>),
and bend forward towards the region of the future mouth.
The rounded angle made by the posterior end of the head-fold is
the first indication of the antennæ. The embryo is now composed
of four well-marked regions: cephalic, maxillary, thoracic, and
abdominal. The primitive band then grows much longer, the
primitive mouth and anus appear, and the appendages bud out,
and eventually the embryo revolves and appears on the ventral side
of the egg (Fig. 525, <span class='small'>6</span>).</p>

<div  class='figcenter id094'>
<img src='images/i_569.jpg' alt='' class='ig001' />
<div class='ic007'>
<p><span class='sc'>Fig. 525.</span>—Early stages in the embryology of <i>Œcanthus niveus</i>. Fig. 1, the youngest observed primitive band, the serosa not yet formed; 2, longitudinal optic section (diagrammatic) of Fig. 1; 3, the primitive band after the appearance of the head-fold, which is indicated at this time by the more rapid growth and consequent greater breadth of the lower end of embryo, x 25; 4, a young embryo after the appearance of the primitive segment-folds, x 50; 5, a more advanced embryo, with the antennal folds distinctly marked off; the free ends of the primitive folds have united across the embryo posterior to the antennal folds, x 50; 6, ventral view of the embryo with the appendages budding out, x 25 (the embryo in this stage lies dormant through the six colder months of the year): <i>am</i>, amnion; <i>m</i>, micropylar end; <i>ch</i>, chorion; <i>gb</i>, primitive band; <i>bf</i>, brain-fold; <i>yl</i>, yolk; <i>tf</i>, caudal fold; <i>kf</i>, head-fold (procephalic
